revision.text:
{{Distinguish|Ace Comics (publishers)}}
{{Infobox comic book title <!--Wikipedia:WikiProject Comics--> | noimage=yes | caption = | schedule = Monthly |format=[[Ongoing series]] |limited = |ongoing =Y | publisher = [[David McKay Publications]] | date = 1937-1949 | main_char_team = | writers = | artists = | pencillers = |sort=Ace Comics |TPB = |ISBN = }} '''''Ace Comics''''' was a comic book series published by [[David McKay Publications]] between 1937 and 1949 — starting just before the [[Golden Age of Comic Books]]. The title reprinted syndicated newspaper strips owned by [[King Features Syndicate]], following the successful formula of a mix of adventure and humor strips introduced by McKay in their ''[[King Comics]]'' title in April 1936; some of the strips transferred from ''King Comics'' from issue #1. ''Ace Comics'' #11, the first appearance of [[The Phantom]], is regarded by many to be a key issue in the history of comics, as it introduced to the comics format one of the first of the costumed heroes, leading to the Golden Age of superheroes in comics.
== Publication history == The first issue of ''Ace Comics'' was published in April 1937, and included the adventures of hunter ''[[Jungle Jim]]'' written by [[Flash Gordon]] writer [[Alex Raymond]], Chic Young's ''[[Blondie (comic strip)|Blondie]]'', and [[George Herriman]]'s surreal ''[[Krazy Kat]]'' strip, all three characters going on to appear in every issue of ''Ace Comics''. Issue #11 (cover date February 1938) is notable as a key Golden Age comic, as it introduced to a wider audience one of the first costumed heroes ever to be featured in a comic book, [[Lee Falk]]'s ''[[The Phantom]]'' — pre-dating ''[[Superman]]'' (''[[Action Comics]]'' #1, cover date June 1938). ''The Phantom'' [[daily strip]], written by [[Ray Moore (comics)|Ray Moore]] and drawn by [[Wilson McCoy]], then featured in ''Ace Comics'' for a 140-issue run, appearing in every issue until the title was cancelled. Initially ''The Phantom'' was a four-page story, but from #38 this was increased to eight pages in each issue. Towards the end of the run, the [[Sunday strip]]s were also included. Many of the strips were edited and cropped from the original newspaper stories, and the text was often rewritten also.
As well as ''Jungle Jim'' and ''The Phantom'', which ran throughout the series, [[Hal Foster]]'s knight's tale of ''[[Prince Valiant]]'' was also a long-running adventure feature, published in issues 26-134. Other adventure strips that appeared included [[Zane Grey]]'s Western character Tex Thorne in early issues, the adventures of orphan Tim Tyler in ''[[Tim Tyler's Luck]]'' and ''{{ill|Curley Harper at Lakespur|fr}}'' both by ''Blondie'' writer/artist Chic Young's brother [[Lyman Young]]. ''Tim Tyler's Luck'' ran in every issue of ''Ace Comics'', while the Curley Harper strip ended with issue 100, although a single strip just called ''Curley Harper'' appeared in issue #107. Later issues reprinted the Flash Gordon-like space adventures of ''[[Brick Bradford]]'' and ''[[The Lone Ranger]]'' strip, both transferred from the ''King Comics'' title.
The ''Blondie'' strip also appeared in every issue of ''Ace Comics'', as did classic the humor strip ''[[The Katzenjammer Kids]]'' by [[Rudolph Dirks]]. Other humor strips included ''[[Pete the Tramp]]'' by [[Clarence D. Russell]], ''[[Tillie the Toiler]]'' by [[Russ Westover]], [[Billy DeBeck]]'s ''[[Barney Google and Snuffy Smith|Barney Google]]'', [[Jimmy Hatlo]]'s ''[[They'll Do It Every Time]]'' and [[Paul Robinson (comics)|Paul Robinson]]'s ''[[Etta Kett]]'' were presented throughout the run, although all of these titles missed the odd issue. The strip ''Seein' Stars'' which ran in the first 50 issues, was written by [http://lambiek.net/artists/b/beeman_arthur.htm Arthur Beeman] and was based around the Hollywood film industry — cartoon versions of a number of Hollywood stars, including [[Fred Astaire]], [[Betty Grable]] and [[Judy Garland]] guested.
Drawn in a similar style to [[Winsor McCay]]'s work, the fantasy strip ''The Pussycat Princess'' (a story originally titled ''Pussycat Princess, A Fairytale For Boys, Girls And Other Children''), by [http://lambiek.net/artists/d/drayton_g.htm Grace Drayton] and Ed Anthony, also featured in early issues of ''Ace Comics'' run. Drayton was a well-known and important early cartoonist who died only a year after starting this delightful fairytale series. Another classic Golden Age artist whose work appeared in a number of issues was [[C. C. Beck#Captain Marvel|C.C.Beck]] (creator of [[Fawcett Comics|Fawcett]]'s [[Captain Marvel (DC Comics)|Captain Marvel]]). Six issues of ''Ace Comics'' contained single-page [http://www.toonopedia.com/tootsie.htm ''Captain Tootsie''] strips - advertisements for [[Tootsie Roll]] confectionery with a short adventure on the page, with a costume patterned on Captain Marvel's.
As well as syndicated strips, most issues also carried text stories,<!--to qualify for magazine mailing rates--> editorials, and factual pages. Many of the stories, such as ''White Buffalo'' in issues #35-36, were written by [[R. G. Montgomery]], who wrote short Western tales in magazines in the 1920s and 1930s. [[Ruth Plumly Thompson]], who wrote a number of the books in the ''[[The Wonderful Wizard of Oz|Oz]]'' series after [[L. Frank Baum]] died in 1919, also wrote a considerable number of editorial pages. ''Ace Comics'' also featured single-panel cartoons, probably the best known of which, [http://www.toonopedia.com/breger.htm ''Private Breger Abroad''], was drawn by celebrated World War II cartoonist [[Dave Breger]]. The factual strip ''[[Ripley's Believe It Or Not!]]'' was reprinted in early issues of ''Ace Comics'', while other factual pages, such as ''Stamp Spotlight'', ''Sports In Pictures'' and ''News In Pictures'', appeared regularly at various times during the run. Two series in 1941-2 covered the early events of World War II at sea — ''Battle of the Atlantic'' and ''Battle for the Seven Seas''. These were written and drawn by [[Edgar Franklin Wittmack]], known for his stylized magazine covers in the 1920s and 1930s.
An unusual feature for the day was the ''Young Reporters'' page, which included [[comic book letter column|readers' letters]] and comments. Competitions and prizes were also advertised in early numbers, and puzzle pages were also featured.
''Ace Comics'' was cancelled with issue #151 (October 1949), although as that issue contained an ad for the next ''Phantom'' series, it can be assumed the decision on cancellation was made after #151 left the printer.
==List of appearances== Below is a list of the main strips ''Ace Comics'' ran throughout the series, with the issues they appeared in. Some long-running series missed the occasional issue, for these the first and last issue of the run is noted. For shorter run titles, the list shows each appearance.
''Information available on issues 1-16 and 133-151 appears to be limited at present. As a result, it has not been possible to produce a definitive list. Issues with a ? against them are the earliest or latest possible issue this character's strip appeared in.''
* ''[[Barney Google and Snuffy Smith|Barney Google]]'' (most issues 1-1 151) * ''Battle of the Atlantic'' issues 55, 57, 58, 60 * ''Battle of the Seven Seas'' issues 61, 66, 70, 72, 73, 75 * ''[[Blondie (comic strip)|Blondie]]'' issues 01–151 * ''[[Brick Bradford]]'' issues 128–151? * ''[http://www.toonopedia.com/tootsie.htm Captain Tootsie]'' issues 76, 86, 87, 90, 99, 100 * ''Curly Harper at Lakespur'' issues 1–100, 107 * ''Cyrano de Bergerac Jnr'' issues 26–32 * ''Daffy Doodles'' (most issues) * ''Dreamland'' (various issues to #20) * ''[http://lambiek.net/artists/w/winner_doc.htm Elmer]''' issues 1–100 * ''[[Etta Kett]]'' issues 1?–37 * ''[[Henry (comic strip)|Henry]]'' (various issues 57–138) * ''[[Jungle Jim]]'' issues 01–? * ''[[Krazy Kat]]'' issues 01–37 * ''[[The Katzenjammer Kids]]'' issues 01–151 * ''[http://www.toonopedia.com/justkids.htm Just Kids]'' issues 1?–100 107 * ''[[The Lone Ranger]]'' issues 135– 151? * ''News in Pictures'' issues 54–70? * ''Nicodemus O'Malley and His Whale, Palsy Walsy'' issues 1?–32 * ''[[Pete the Tramp]]'' (most issues 1–151) * ''[[The Phantom]]'' issues 11–151 * ''[[Prince Valiant]]'' issues 26–134 * ''[[Dave Breger#Private Breger|Private Breger Abroad]]'' (most issues 72–106) * ''Private Buck'' issue 57 * ''Pussycat Princess'' issues 10?–37 * ''[[Ripley's Believe It or Not!]]'' issues 01–26? * ''[[Room and Board (comic strip)|Room and Board]]'' issues 1?–50? * ''Seein' Stars'' issues 1?–65 * ''Sport in Pictures'' (various issues from 1–74?) * ''Teddy And Sitting Bull'' issues 1?–151? * ''Tex Thorne'' issue 1–14? * ''[[They'll Do It Every Time]]'' issues 10?–127? * ''[[Tillie the Toiler]]'' (most issues 1?–127) * ''[[Tim Tyler's Luck]]'' issues 1–151
==See also== *[[King Comics]]
==References== {{refbegin}} * Goulart, Ron. ''Comic Book Culture, A History'' * [http://www.cbgxtra.com/Default.aspx?tabid=42&view=topic&forumid=16&postid=3184 Comic Buyer's Guide Standard Catalog of Comic Books, 5th Edition, 2008 by Maggie Thompson, Brent Frankenhoff and Peter Bickford, Krause Publications, ''cd release'' ] * [http://www.toonopedia.com/ Don Marks' Toonopedia] * [http://www.comics.org/ The Grand Comics Database] * The [[Overstreet]] Comic Book Price Guide {{refend}}
==External links== *[http://digitalcomicmuseum.com/index.php?cid=98 Ace Comics at the Digital Comic Museum]

[[English language|English]]
[[Persian language|Persian]] | budget = | gross = }} {{italic title}} '''''Ali's Wedding''''' is a 2017 Australian romantic comedy feature film from [[Matchbox Pictures]].{{cite web|url=https://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/movies/short-cuts-alis-wedding-draws-on-muslim-stars-colourful-life-20151110-gkv6gb.html|title=Short Cuts: Ali's Wedding draws on Muslim star's colourful life|first=Garry|last=Maddox|date=11 November 2015|website=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|publisher=[[Fairfax Media]]|accessdate=22 June 2018}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/movies/australias-first-muslim-romcom-movie-alis-wedding-hopes-to-disarm-haters-as-it-hits-big-screen-20161031-gsewjd.html|title=Australia's first Muslim rom-com movie, Ali's Wedding, hopes to disarm haters as it hits big screen|date=31 October 2016|access-date=13 May 2017|website=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|publisher=[[Fairfax Media]]|first=Garry|last=Maddox}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.betacinema.com/aliswedding|title=Ali's Wedding|publisher=Beta Cinema|access-date=13 May 2017}} It is directed by [[Jeffrey Walker (actor)|Jeffrey Walker]] and written by [[Osamah Sami]] and stars Sami, [[Helana Sawires]], [[Don Hany]] and [[Ryan Corr]]. Sami has been quoted as saying that the film is "history making, the first Muslim rom-com, so it's going to hopefully pave the way for many other similar stories, not just from the Muslim community but from other communities and minorities in our society." He said that the "affectionate and poignant story of love" was trying to cast a more positive light on Muslim-Australian life. == Plot == Ali ([[Osamah Sami]]), the charming and musically-talented son of a Muslim cleric ([[Don Hany]]), struggles to make the right life choices despite the best of intentions. He wants to be with the girl, Dianne ([[Helana Sawires]]), he loves, but he's been promised to another girl at his father's mosque. He wants to be the great doctor that the community expects him to be, but he doesn't get the marks. Above all, he wants to make his father proud. To live up to these impossible expectations, he lies about his academic achievements, and then his quest to please his father spirals out of control, with amusing and poignant consequences.{{cite web|title=Ali's Wedding|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2782692/?ref_=nm_knf_t1|publisher=[[IMDb]]|accessdate=13 May 2017}} == Cast == *[[Osamah Sami]] as Ali Albasri *[[Don Hany]] as Sheik Mahdi *[[Helana Sawires]] as Dianne Mohsen *Frances Duca as Zahra *Khaled Khalafalla as Moe Greene *Asal Shenavehzadeh as Ramona *Majid Shokor as Seyyed Ghaffar *Shayan Salehian as Luay *Ghazi Alkinani as Abu Faisal *Rodney Afif as Haj Karim *Maha Wilson as Yomna *Natalie Gamsu as Fatima *[[Robert Rabiah]] as Mohsen *Rahel Romahn as Ayoob *[[Aljin Abella]] as Chris *[[Ryan Corr]] as Wazza ==Release== ''Ali's Wedding'' premiered at the [[Adelaide Film Festival]] in October 2016.{{cite web|url=http://screen.artshub.com.au/news-article/company-announcements/film/screenhub/matchbox-alis-wedding-shoot-starts-249815|title=Matchbox: Ali's Wedding shoot starts|author=ScreenHub|work=ScreenHub|date=9 November 2015|accessdate=22 June 2018}}{{Cite web|url=https://adelaidefilmfestival.org/sessions/15533|title=Ali's Wedding|website=[[Adelaide Film Festival]]|publisher=South Australia Film Corporation|access-date=13 May 2017}} It also showed at the [[Sydney Film Festival]] on 8 June 2017.{{Cite web|url=http://tix.sff.org.au/session_sff.asp?sn=Ali's+Wedding|title=Ali's Wedding|publisher=[[Sydney Film Festival]]|access-date=13 May 2017|dead-url=yes}}{{dead link|fix-attempted=yes|date=June 2018}}{{Cite news|url=http://junkee.com/alis-wedding-muslim-rom-com/104923|title=Australia’s First Muslim Rom-Com ‘Ali’s Wedding’ Finally Has A Trailer!|date=10 May 2017|work=[[Junkee]]|access-date=13 May 2017|first=Matilda|last=Dixon-Smith}} ==Reception== On [[review aggregator]] website [[Rotten Tomatoes]], the film holds an approval rating of 92%, based on 24 reviews, and an [[average rating]] of 7/10.{{cite web |url=https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/alis_wedding |title=Ali's Wedding (2018) |work=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] |publisher=[[Fandango (company)|Fandango Media]] |accessdate=27 June 2018}} On [[Metacritic]], the film has a weighted average score of 64 out of 100, based on 4 critics, indicating "generally favorable reviews".{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/alis-wedding |title=Ali's Wedding Reviews |work=[[Metacritic]] |publisher=[[CBS Interactive]] |accessdate=22 June 2018}} ==Accolades== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Award ! Category ! Subject ! Result |- |rowspan=10|[[AACTA Awards]]
([[7th AACTA Awards|7th]]) |rowspan=2|[[AACTA Award for Best Film|Best Film]] |Sheila Jayadev |{{nom}} |- |Helen Panckhurst |{{nom}} |- |[[AACTA Award for Best Direction|Best Direction]] |[[Jeffrey Walker (actor)|Jeffrey Walker]] |{{nom}} |- |rowspan=2|[[AACTA Award for Best Original Screenplay|Best Original Screenplay]] |[[Andrew Knight (writer)|Andrew Knight]] |{{won}} |- |rowspan=2|[[Osamah Sami]] |{{won}} |- |[[AACTA Award for Best Actor in a Leading Role|Best Actor]] |{{nom}} |- |[[AACTA Award for Best Actress in a Leading Role|Best Actress]] |[[Helana Sawires]] |{{nom}} |- |[[AACTA Award for Best Actor in a Supporting Role|Best Supporting Actor]] |[[Don Hany]] |{{nom}} |- |[[AACTA Award for Best Actress in a Supporting Role|Best Supporting Actress]] |Frances Duca |{{nom}} |- |[[AACTA Award for Best Original Music Score|Best Original Music Score]] |[[Nigel Westlake]] |{{nom}} |- |} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://aliswedding.com.au ''Ali's Wedding'' official website] * {{IMDb title|2782692}} [[Category:2016 films]] [[Category:Australian films]] [[Category:Australian drama films]] [[Category:Australian comedy films]] [[Category:Films set in Melbourne]] [[Category:Films shot in Melbourne]] [[Category:Australian comedy-drama films]] [[Category:Films based on biographies]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Films based on works by Australian writers]] [[Category:Islamic comedy and humor]]

revision.text:
'''''Aztec Ace''''' is a comic title formerly published by [[Eclipse Comics]]. Originally written by [[Doug Moench]] and pencilled by [[Dan Day]], 15 issues appeared from 1984 to 1985.<ref name= "chills">{{cite news |last=McCulloch |first=Joe |url= http://www.tcj.com/this-week-in-comics-32311-multifarious-chills/ |title=THIS WEEK IN COMICS! (3/23/11 – Multifarious Chills!) |work=[[The Comics Journal]] |date=March 22, 2011 |accessdate=June 8, 2017}}</ref> (The characters reappeared in the 1988 ''[[Total Eclipse (comic)|Total Eclipse]]'' comic series.) Other contributors to Aztec Ace were inker [[Nestor Redondo]], inker [[Ron Harris (artist)|Ron Harris]], artist [[Mike Gustovich]], artist [[Tom Yeates]], colorist [[Philip DeWalt]], colorist [[Steve Oliff]], colorist [[Sam Parsons]], letterer [[Carrie Spiegle]], and Eclipse editor [[catherine yronwode|cat yronwode]]. The Aztec Ace logo was created by [[Denis McFarling]].
The story revolves around a time traveller named Ace (real name: Caza), whose goal is to save the timestream from unraveling through various intricate adventures. Ace is from the 23rd Century, with his base in pre-contact Aztec Mexico; he often visits ancient Egypt. His main enemy is Nine-Crocodile, who creates time paradoxes in an attempt to save his own dimension at the expense of other realities, especially, the modern world as we know it.
Characteristics of the series are time travel, the use of cultural icons such as political figures, historical situations, songs, and cult movies in unexpected situations, and philosophical musing. Historical renderings of ancient cultures were detailed and imaginative. Careful reading, broad knowledge, and patience were required of the reader, as well as some understanding of the ongoing storyline, all of which possibly prevented it from gathering a large following.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.denismcfarling.com/pages/GraphicArt/Design/AztecAce.html Sketchings of the Unfinished and Finished Versions of the Aztec Ace Logo] *[http://www.internationalhero.co.uk/a/aztecace.htm International Hero Catalog on Aztec Ace] {{comics-stub}} [[Category:Comics by Doug Moench]] [[Category:Eclipse Comics characters]] [[Category:Eclipse Comics titles]] [[Category:Comics about time travel]]

'''Bevis Hillier''' (born 28 March 1940) is an English [[art historian]], author and journalist. He has written on [[Art Deco]], and also a [[biography]] of [[John Betjeman|Sir John Betjeman]].
==Life and work== Hillier was born in [[Redhill, Surrey]]. His father was [[Jack Hillier (art historian)|Jack Hillier]], an authority and author on [[Japanese art]]. His mother was Mary Louise Hillier, an authority on wax dolls and [[automata]]. Hillier was educated at [[Reigate Grammar School]] and [[Magdalen College, Oxford]], where he won the Gladstone Memorial Prize for History. He was employed as a [[journalist]] on ''[[The Times]]'' from 1963. He has since been a reviewer for ''[[The Spectator]]''.
In 1968 Hillier's book ''[[Art Deco of the 20s and 30s]]'' was published by Studio Vista. This was the first major work on a hitherto neglected genre of art that had previously been referred to as [[Art Moderne]] (The term ''Art Moderne'' has since come to be used to refer to the later ''streamlined'' style of Art Deco in the 1930s.). Hillier's use of the term ''[[Art Deco]]'' became definitive. In 1971 Hillier curated a major Art Deco show at the [[Minneapolis Institute of Arts]], which helped to increase popular awareness of this style.
In 1969 Studio Vista published Hillier's ''Cartoons and Caricatures'', a study of caricature from the 13th century to the late 20th. Hillier has also written books on ceramics and posters, as well as ''The Style of the Century'' (1983), a review of the various styles of art in the 20th century, from [[Art Nouveau]] through [[psychedelia]] and [[pop art]] to [[Punk art|punk]].
Hillier's major work, however, is the authorised biography of Sir [[John Betjeman]]. It took Hillier 25 years to research and write, and was published by [[John Murray (publisher)|John Murray]] in three volumes (1988, 2002 and 2004). A one-volume abridgement was published in 2006 for Betjeman's centenary.
==Betjeman letter hoax== In August 2006 a rival biography of Betjeman was published by [[A. N. Wilson]]. It was later discovered to contain a hoax letter, purportedly by Betjeman, but actually containing an [[acrostic]] insulting Wilson. The letter had been sent to Wilson by "Eve de Harben", an anagram of "Ever been had?", and the first letters of each sentence, beginning with the second sentence, spelled out the message "A.N. Wilson is a shit." Hillier was an immediate suspect for the [[literary forgery]]: the ''[[The Sunday Times (UK)|Sunday Times]]'' article revealing the hoax was accompanied by a prominent picture of Hillier and noted that an envelope containing a letter supposedly from de Harben to the newspaper had been bought in [[Winchester]], his home town.<ref name="hoax">{{cite news | last = Brooks | first = Richard | title = Betjeman love letter is horrid hoax | publisher = The Sunday Times | date = 2006-08-27 | url = http://www.timesonline.co.uk/article/0,,2087-2330457,00.html | accessdate = 2006-08-28 | location=London}}</ref> Hillier initially denied responsibility, but soon admitted that he had written the letter. He explained that he had been angered by Wilson's negative review of the second volume of his biography of Betjeman, and by pre-publication publicity for Wilson's own biography.<ref name="hoax-confession">{{cite news | last = Brooks | first = Richard | title = Betjeman biographer confesses to literary hoax | publisher = The Sunday Times | date = 2006-09-03 | url = http://www.timesonline.co.uk/article/0,,2087-2340567,00.html | accessdate = 2006-09-05 | location=London}}</ref>
==Bibliography== ===Books=== *''[[Art Deco of the 20s and 30s]]'' (Studio Vista/Dutton Picturebacks, 1968) {{ISBN|978-0-289-27788-1}} *''The Decorative Arts of the Forties and Fifties: Austerity/Binge'' ([[Clarkson N. Potter Publishers|Clarkson N. Potter]], 1975) {{ISBN|0-517-518503}} *''Bevis Hillier's Pocket Guide to Antiques'' (Mitchell Beazley, 1981) {{ISBN|0-855-333170}} *''John Betjeman: A Life in Pictures'' (John Murray, 1984) {{ISBN|0-719-541816}} *''Young Betjeman'' (John Murray, 1988) {{ISBN|0-719-545315}} *''John Betjeman: New Fame, New Love, 1934-1958'' (John Murray, 2002) {{ISBN|0-719-550025}} *''Betjeman: The Bonus of Laughter'' (John Murray, 2004) {{ISBN|0-719-564956}} *''The Virgin's Baby: The Battle of the Ampthill Succession'' (Hopcyn Press, 2013) {{ISBN|978-0-957-29776-0}}
===Articles=== *{{cite journal |last=Hillier |first=Bevis |date=4 October 2008 |title=A laughing cavalier |journal=[[The Spectator]] |volume=308 |issue=9397 |pages=32–34 |url=http://www.spectator.co.uk/the-magazine/books/2188531/a-laughing-cavalier.thtml |accessdate=22 December 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081204193411/http://www.spectator.co.uk/the-magazine/books/2188531/a-laughing-cavalier.thtml |archivedate=4 December 2008 |df= }} Review of James Knox, ''Cartoons and Coronets: The Genius of [[Osbert Lancaster]]'' (Frances Lincoln, 2008) {{ISBN|978-0-7112-2933-4}}.
==References== <references/>
==External links== *[http://books.guardian.co.uk/reviews/poetry/0,6121,1339954,00.html Review of the third volume of Hillier's biography of Betjeman]

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2017}} {{Use Indian English|date=April 2017}} '''Bharatiya Lok Kala Mandal''' is a cultural institution based in [[Udaipur]] in [[Rajasthan]] state in [[India]] engaged in studying folk art, culture, songs and festivals of Rajasthan, [[Gujarat]] and [[Madhya Pradesh]] and to popularise and propagate folk arts, folk dances and folk literature. It was set up in 1952 by [[Devilal Samar]]. The institution has a museum that exhibits collection of folk articles from Rajasthan like rural-dresses, ornaments, puppets, masks, dolls, folk musical instruments, folk deities and paintings. There is [[puppet]] theater ([[Kathputli (Puppet)|Kathputli]]) too where puppet shows are held at regular intervals.
== Museum == It includes a museum dedicated to folk art of Rajasthan.
; Wall sculptures <gallery> File:Chavanda Mata, folk art, Bharatiya Lok Kala Museum, Udaipur, India.jpg|Chavanda Mata File:Amaj Mata, folk art, Bharatiya Lok Kala Museum, Udaipur, India.jpg|Amaj Mata File:Narsing Mata, folk art, Bharatiya Lok Kala Museum, Udaipur, India.jpg|Narsing Mata File:Kala Bheru, folk art, Bharatiya Lok Kala Museum, Udaipur, India.jpg|Kala Bheru File:Sadu Mata, folk art, Bharatiya Lok Kala Museum, Udaipur, India.jpg|Sadu Mata File:Kalaji - Goraji, folk art, Bharatiya Lok Kala Museum, Udaipur, India.jpg|Kalaji - Goraji File:Sand Mata, folk art, Bharatiya Lok Kala Museum, Udaipur, India.jpg|Sand Mata File:Rebari dev, folk art, Bharatiya Lok Kala Museum, Udaipur, India.jpg|Rebari dev File:Ramu-Keval Devi, folk art, Bharatiya Lok Kala Museum, Udaipur, India.jpg|Ramu-Keval Devi File:Bearded knight with scepter, folk art, Bharatiya Lok Kala Museum, Udaipur, India.jpg File:Bearded knight with lance, folk art, Bharatiya Lok Kala Museum, Udaipur, India.jpg File:Knight with lance, folk art, Bharatiya Lok Kala Museum, Udaipur, India.jpg File:Four-arm goddess on a tiger, folk art, Bharatiya Lok Kala Museum, Udaipur, India.jpg File:Four-arm goddess on a horse, folk art, Bharatiya Lok Kala Museum, Udaipur, India.jpg </gallery>
; Other items <gallery> File:Ritual pots, Bharatiya Lok Kala Museum, Udaipur, India.jpg|Ritual pots File:Yellow mask of woman, folk art, Bharatiya Lok Kala Museum, Udaipur, India.jpg|Mask File:Ganesh, folk art, Bharatiya Lok Kala Museum, Udaipur, India.jpg|Painting of Ganesha File:Mataji ka devra, folk art, Bharatiya Lok Kala Museum, Udaipur, India.jpg|Place of worship for Mataji File:Woman in red sari performing puja, folk art, Bharatiya Lok Kala Museum, Udaipur, India.jpg|Wood painting File:Ganesh and other characters, folk art, Bharatiya Lok Kala Museum, Udaipur, India.jpg File:Wedding, folk art, Bharatiya Lok Kala Museum, Udaipur, India.jpg|Drawing File:Radha, Krishna and the gopis, Bharatiya Lok Kala Museum, Udaipur, India.jpg|Radha, Krishna and the gopis File:Hanuman (Ramleela), folk art, Bharatiya Lok Kala Museum, Udaipur, India.jpg|Hanuman (Ramleela) File:Kanjari, folk art, Bharatiya Lok Kala Museum, Udaipur, India.jpg|Full-sized puppet File:Rai, folk art, Bharatiya Lok Kala Museum, Udaipur, India.jpg|Full-sized puppet File:Bhopa, folk art, Bharatiya Lok Kala Museum, Udaipur, India.jpg|Full-sized puppet File:Bhopin, folk art, Bharatiya Lok Kala Museum, Udaipur, India.jpg|Full-sized puppet File:Kanjar, folk art, Bharatiya Lok Kala Museum, Udaipur, India.jpg|Full-sized puppet File:Raibudia, Bharatiya Lok Kala Museum, Udaipur, India.jpg|Full-sized puppet with mask File:Design for henna tattoos, Bharatiya Lok Kala Museum, Udaipur, India.jpg|Design for henna tattoos File:Hirna Raxas, folk art, Bharatiya Lok Kala Museum, Udaipur, India.jpg File:Hirannakush, folk art, Bharatiya Lok Kala Museum, Udaipur, India.jpg </gallery>

{{Infobox video game |title = Blaster Master 2 |image = Blastermaster2 boxart.jpg |developer = [[Software Creations (UK)|Software Creations]][http://www.gamefaqs.com/genesis/586067-blaster-master-2/data ''Blaster Master 2''] at [[GameFAQs]] |publisher = [[Sunsoft]] |composer = Tony Williams |series = |released = {{vgrelease|NA|1993}} |genre = [[Shoot 'em up#Run and gun|Run and gun]] |modes = [[Single-player video game|Single-player]] |platforms = [[Sega Genesis]] }} '''''Blaster Master 2''''' is a [[video game]] developed by [[Software Creations (UK)|Software Creations]] and published exclusively in [[North America]] by [[Sunsoft|Sunsoft of America]] for the [[Sega Genesis]] on March 15, 1993. The game is a [[sequel]] to the original ''[[Blaster Master]]'' originally published for the Nintendo Entertainment System (NES). It was published specifically for the [[North America]]n market following the success of the first NES game in the same region. The staff of the original Japanese version of ''Blaster Master'', titled ''Chô Wakusei Senki Metafight'', had nothing to do with ''Blaster Master 2'', and Sunsoft Japan did not release BM2 in Japan. == Plot == The game takes place four years after Jason's Encounter with the Plutonium Boss and the [[Radioactive decay|radioactive]] mutants under the [[Earth]].[http://www.mobygames.com/game/blaster-master-2 ''Blaster Master 2''] at [[MobyGames]] His only reminder of the incident is [[SOPHIA (vehicle)|S.O.P.H.I.A.]], the vehicle he used to stop them, which he has hidden in an abandoned barn. One day, one bolt of lightning struck the house and caused the ceiling to crumble, knocking Jason [[Unconsciousness|unconscious]]. When Jason woke up, S.O.P.H.I.A. was in pieces and the parts he had collected from his first dealings with the Mutant Bosses were missing. Little does Jason know that there are more lightning beings where the first one came from and they are planning to destroy the Earth. The beings started digging towards the Earth's core in order to shift the planet's weight off its axis, leading to total [[annihilation]]. The parts from SOPHIA are being used to create a robotic army to assist the being in accomplishing their mission. Now, Jason must stop them, but he won't make it without the help of SOPHIA. Since he can't recover the parts, he decided to redesign it to better prepare himself for the ordeal facing him. After 29 days, SOPHIA was completely rebuilt and ready for battle. Remembering where he saw the being's footsteps, Jason jumped in his vehicle and headed towards the mountains where the challenge begins. === Characters === '''Jason Frudnick''' - He is the protagonist throughout the ''Blaster Master'' series. He is the character that accidentally discovered SOPHIA while trying to retrieve his pet frog Fred. In ''Blaster Master 2'', Jason is young (age 19) and couldn't have been more prepared for battle. His job is to eliminate the Plutonium Boss once and for all. Jason's equipment is fairly simple in ''Blaster Master 2''. He is wearing body armor that has moderate protection from heat and impact. Jason also comes with his usual blast cannon that is equipped onto his left arm brace. It does not overheat, and has unlimited energy. In ''Blaster Master 2'', Jason is mostly seen inside SOPHIA's canopy, but can easily hop out at any time in the game when in the sidescroll view. Jason does not take impact from falling too well in BM2, but when in the "Jason view" he does not take damage from falling impact. Jason is more easily seen in detail when challenging a boss or even an underboss. He is approximately ten times larger in this view. '''[[SOPHIA (vehicle)|S.O.P.H.I.A.]]''' (sometimes referred to as '''SOPHIA''') - The robotic, combat tank-like vehicle used throughout the ''Blaster Master'' series. SOPHIA comes in many different models, and the one that is seen in ''Blaster Master 2'' is SOPHIA 4th (2000). The model has been rebuilt by Jason and has many new and helpful features from the previous models of SOPHIA ([[SOPHIA (vehicle)#SOPHIA 3rd .28Nora MA-01.29|SOPHIA Nora MA-01]], [[SOPHIA (vehicle)#SOPHIA 3rd .28Nora MA-02.29|SOPHIA Nora MA-02]]). == Gameplay == Under the development team of Software Creations and the marketing team at [[Sunsoft|Sunsoft of America]], several things were altered in the new ''Blaster Master 2'' game, such as the name of the vehicle (now "S.O.P.H.I.A."), as well as significantly expanded gameplay. There are now 8 levels to play through, and each level containing a [[power-up]] or new obtainable weapon in which Jason or SOPHIA can use throughout the game. The platform-jumping characteristics that made the [[Blaster Master|original]] [[NES]] game so popular among fans were preserved, while other viewpoints provided an additional level of gameplay unique to BM2 alone. There were now three ways to play: sidescroll view (S.O.P.H.I.A. and Jason), overhead view (S.O.P.H.I.A.), and Jason running through rooms (with a large view, and a small view with Jason running through certain parts of the stages). === Sidescroll view === [[Image:Bm2 sideview.jpg|100px|left|Normal view of SOPHIA]]In the sidescroll view, players battled through levels just like in ''[[Blaster Master]]'', except in 16-bit graphics. Jason could get powerups such as homing missile, three-way missiles, bubble shield, and lightning spread.
 
=== Overhead view === [[Image:Bm2 topview.jpg|100px|left|Overhead view of SOPHIA]]In the overhead view, S.O.P.H.I.A. can not use upgrades, but instead could rotate the turret 360 degrees while the player runs through obstacles and gunfire. S.O.P.H.I.A. rotates her turret differently than when in the sidescroll view. A tap of the B and C buttons on the Genesis controller will rotate left and right.
 
=== Jason view === [[Image:Bm2 jasonboss.jpg|100px|left|Large view of Jason]]During the course of the game, Jason could enter several rooms, one of which may contain a mini-boss (such as a giant bee or worm) that he must fight in order to gain a powerup or key that will let him enter the next stage. Sometimes these mini-bosses will give Jason or S.O.P.H.I.A. a powerup that enhances their abilities. For example, Jason can get a jetpack, or missile launcher. S.O.P.H.I.A. can get a hover module, or a drill that can break through stone.
 
== Reviews == ''[[Electronic Gaming Monthly]]'' scored the game 7 out of 10. Their four reviewers were divided about the game; one hailed it as having "better graphics, better sounds, and better play" than the original ''Blaster Master'', one expressed disappointment over the removal of some of the original's power-ups but judged it an overall solid sequel, and the remaining two felt the game to be merely average.{{cite journal|last= |first= |title=Review Crew: Blaster Master 2|journal=[[Electronic Gaming Monthly]]|issue=47|publisher=EGM Media, LLC|date=June 1993|page=30}} == References == {{reflist}} == External links == *[http://bmunderground.com/ Blaster Master Underground (BMUG)] - a complete record of all games in the series, including external media and background development history on each game {{Blaster Master series}} [[Category:1993 video games]] [[Category:Metroidvania games]] [[Category:North America-exclusive video games]] [[Category:Platform games]] [[Category:Run and gun games]] [[Category:Science fiction video games]] [[Category:Sega Genesis games]] [[Category:Sega Genesis-only games]] [[Category:Software Creations (UK) games]] [[Category:Sunsoft games]] [[Category:Video game sequels]] [[Category:Video games developed in the United Kingdom]]

{{for|the [[Mega Man]] enemy|Robot Master}}
{{Infobox character | colour = #DEDEE2 | colour text = | name = Blizzard Man | series = [[Saturday Night Live]] | image = | caption = | first = November 18, 2006 | last = May 17, 2014 | creator = | portrayer = [[Andy Samberg]] | nickname = Blizz, Blizzard the Wizard, Blizzy B, Blizz Nasty | alias = | species = | gender = Male | occupation = | title = | family = | spouse = | significantother = | children = | relatives = | religion = | nationality = }}
'''''Blizzard Man''''' is a skit by [[Andy Samberg]] on American television program on ''[[Saturday Night Live]]''. The skit prominently features Samberg as the title character, who is brought in recording studios to assist musicians with an in-progress song, only for them to find that his musical ability is limited to a cheesy parody of serious [[rap music]]. Despite this, the skit always concludes with the artists recording with him anyway. Guests stars for the skit in the past have included [[Ludacris]], [[T-Pain]], [[P. Diddy]], [[Common (rapper)|Common]], and [[2 Chainz]] as themselves and [[Tim McGraw]] and [[Robert De Niro]] playing fictional characters.
==Format== The skit's premise is typically that a music producer<ref name="billboard.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/viral-videos/949701/watch-diddy-grinds-with-robert-deniro-on-snl|title=Watch: Diddy Grinds With Robert DeNiro on 'SNL'|publisher=Billboard|accessdate=10 June 2016}}</ref> is looking for additional talent in recording a [[rap music|rap song]] with another musician. The producer will suggest recruiting Blizzard Man for help. Typically the producer speaks very highly of Blizzard Man, making bold claims such as that his rapping rivals other popular artists, such as [[Trey Songz]] or [[Bruno Mars]], only to see that Blizzard Man looks like [[Vanilla Ice]], has terrible vocals and laughable lyrics.<ref name="billboard.com"/> To make things worse, he often uses nonsensical 1990s-inspired catchphrases such as "Word is bond" and "What it do?" while alluding to similarly outdated things such as [[Jordache|Jordache jeans]] or claiming that it is actually 1995.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://certifiedrandom.com/articles/snl-ludacris-replaces-t-pain-with-blizzard-man/2278 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=May 29, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110625111935/http://certifiedrandom.com/articles/snl-ludacris-replaces-t-pain-with-blizzard-man/2278 |archivedate=June 25, 2011 }}</ref> Typically, the character is in the recording musician role and [[Kenan Thompson]], playing a recording engineer in the studio, right away strongly opposes Blizzard Man's music and mannerisms, but as the skit progresses, they are eventually swayed by Blizzard Man's performances (which, in reality, never change or actually get better), and the enthusiasm of the producer.<ref name="rapdirt.com">{{cite web|url=http://rapdirt.com/ludacris-and-t-pain-meet-blizzard-man/17924/|title=Ludacris And T-Pain Meet Blizzard Man |website=Rapdirt.com|accessdate=10 June 2016}}</ref>
==Episodes== ===November 18, 2006=== In the original skit, ''Saturday Night Live'' cast members [[Jason Sudeikis]] and [[Maya Rudolph]] play record producers, and [[Ludacris]] guest stars, as himself, as a musician who acknowledges he needs help with his newest recording.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://snltranscripts.jt.org/06/06fblizzard.phtml|title=SNL Transcripts: Ludacris: 11/18/06: The Blizzard Man|website=Snltranscripts.jt.org|accessdate=10 June 2016}}</ref> Unlike the later variations of the skit, the musician, Ludacris, is trying to convince the record producers that Blizzard Man should be utilized as a musician. Ludacris ultimately succeeds in convincing them.
===January 20, 2007=== [[Jeremy Piven]] guest stars as the music producer who supports Blizzard Man.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tvguide.com/celebrities/afi/280920|title=AFI|website=Tvguide.com|accessdate=10 June 2016}}</ref> [[Common (rapper)|Common]] guest stars as the musician who initially opposes, but eventually embraces, recording with him.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tv.ign.com/articles/758/758352p1.html|title=Saturday Night Live: "Jeremy Piven / AFI" Review|first=By Larry|last=Carroll|website=Tv.ign.com|accessdate=10 June 2016}}</ref>
===November 22, 2008=== [[Tim McGraw]] guest stars as Blizzard Man's manager.<ref name="rapdirt.com"/> Ludacris guest stars, as himself, as the music producer who supports Blizzard Man, and [[T-Pain]] guest stars, as himself, as the musician who is initially opposed, but eventually embraces, recording with him.<ref name="rapdirt.com"/>
===December 4, 2010=== [[Robert De Niro]] guest stars as Blizzard Man's mother.<ref name="mtv.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1653566/diddy-robert-deniro-flirt-on-saturday-night-live.jhtml|title=Diddy And Robert DeNiro Flirt On 'Saturday Night Live'|website=Mtv.com|accessdate=10 June 2016}}</ref> [[Sean Combs]] (P. Diddy) guest stars, as himself, as the music producer that supports Blizzard Man.<ref name="mtv.com"/>
===May 17, 2014=== [[2 Chainz]] guest stars, as himself, as the music producer that supports Blizzard Man.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rap-up.com/2014/05/18/2-chainz-co-signs-blizzard-man-in-snl-skit/|title=2 Chainz Co-Signs Blizzard Man in 'SNL' Skit|website=Rap-up.com|accessdate=10 June 2016}}</ref>
===Outside SNL=== In 2007, to promote Ludacris donating a motorcycle to a charity auction, he and Samberg created an additional skit, not shown on SNL.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.ebay.com/usr/harley-supports-ludacris-foundation |title=Archived copy |access-date=2018-06-16 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180616030551/https://www.ebay.com/usr/harley-supports-ludacris-foundation |archive-date=2018-06-16 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> The skit involves Ludacris looking for a rapper to advertise for said auction, which results with him eventually deciding on Blizzard Man's song.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.prweb.com/releases/2007/05/prweb526645.htm|title=Live eBay Auction Offering Brand New 2007 Harley-Davidson FLSTF Fat Boy Motorcycle, Proceeds to Benefit The Ludacris Foundation|website=Prweb.com|accessdate=10 June 2016}}</ref>
==Reception== Reception for the skit has been mostly positive, especially the episode featuring Robert De Niro. ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' called it a "home run", especially praising De Niro's role in drag as Blizzard Man's mother.<ref name="billboard.com"/> [[MTV]] also praised it, calling it "one of the highlights of the episode," especially the prospect of Diddy and De Niro flirting with each other.<ref name="mtv.com"/> [[Movieline]] was positive as well, calling it one of the De Niro's sketches that "delivered A-material".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://movieline.com/2010/12/06/who-scored-big-in-week-eight-of-snls-not-ready-for-prime-time-player-relevancy-poll/|title=Who Scored Big in Week Eight of SNL's Not-Ready-for-Prime-Time-Player Relevancy Poll?|first=Mike|last=Ryan|date=6 December 2010|website=Movieline.com|accessdate=10 June 2016}}</ref> ''PopCrunch'' said of the skit, "nobody does dorky white rapper like Samberg",<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tv.popcrunch.com/watch-snl-blizzard-man-diddy-robert-de-niro-video/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=May 29, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110211025033/http://tv.popcrunch.com/watch-snl-blizzard-man-diddy-robert-de-niro-video/ |archivedate=February 11, 2011 }}</ref> while the [[Huffington Post]] used the skit as an example of how legendary actor Robert De Niro never got sillier.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/12/05/blizzard-man-robert-de-ni_n_792235.html|title=WATCH: Robert De Niro Grinds With Diddy In 'SNL' Sketch|date=5 December 2010|publisher=[[Huffington Post]]|accessdate=10 June 2016}}</ref> [[Zap2it]] described it as "kind of hilarious" and concluded "we gotta give props to Diddy hitting on him (her) and declaring, 'If you weren't my man's mom, I'd tear that ass up.'"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.zap2it.com/frominsidethebox/2010/12/saturday-night-live-robert-de-niro-gets-help-from-ben-stiller.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101208042538/http://blog.zap2it.com/frominsidethebox/2010/12/saturday-night-live-robert-de-niro-gets-help-from-ben-stiller.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=8 December 2010|title='Saturday Night Live': Robert De Niro gets help from Ben Stiller|date=5 December 2010|website=Blog.zap2it.com|accessdate=10 June 2016}}</ref>
Other ''Blizzard Man'' sketches were praised as well. ''Prefix Mag'' called the T Pain, Ludacris, and Tim McGraw episode "hilarious" and urged readers to watch it.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.prefixmag.com/news/t-pain-and-ludacris-meet-the-blizzard-man-on-snl-v/23295/|title=T-Pain and Ludacris meet The Blizzard Man on SNL (Video)|website=Prefixmag.com|accessdate=10 June 2016}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}

revision.text:
{{distinguish|Blood Bowl (1995 video game)}} {{Infobox video game | title = Blood Bowl | image = Blood Bowl.jpg | caption = Cover art of ''Blood Bowl'' | developer = [[Cyanide (company)|Cyanide]] | publisher = [[Focus Home Interactive]] | released = '''Microsoft Windows'''{{vgrelease|WW|June 26, 2009 (digital)}}{{vgrelease|[[France|FR]] / [[Spain|SP]] / [[Germany|GER]]|June 26, 2009 (retail)}}{{vgrelease|[[Australia|AUS]]|October 22, 2009 (retail)}}'''Xbox 360'''{{vgrelease|WW|January 26, 2010}}'''iOS'''{{vgrelease|WW|July 30, 2014}}'''PlayStation Portable'''{{vgrelease|NA|April 13, 2010}} | genre = [[Sports game|Sports]], [[real-time strategy]], [[turn-based strategy]] | modes = [[Single-player]], [[Multiplayer video game|multiplayer]] | platforms = [[Microsoft Windows]], [[Xbox 360]], [[PlayStation Portable]], [[Nintendo DS]], [[iOS]] }} '''''Blood Bowl''''' is a [[fantasy football (board games)|fantasy football]] [[video game]] developed by [[Cyanide (company)|Cyanide]], loosely based on [[American football]], and adapted from the [[Blood Bowl|board game of the same name]], which is produced by [[Games Workshop]], using the [[Blood Bowl#Living Rulebook|CRP]] ruleset. ==Gameplay== The game is a [[fantasy]] version of American football, played between two teams of up to 16 players, each team fielding up to 11 players at a time. [[Touchdown]]s are scored by taking the ball into the opposition's end zone, and a team can win either by scoring the most touchdowns, or by violently eliminating the other team's entire roster.{{cite web |url=http://www.gameshark.com/features/569/Blood-Bowl-Q&A-with-Cyanide-CEO-Patrick-Pligersdorffer.htm |title=Blood Bowl Q&A with Cyanide CEO Patrick Pligersdorffer |author=Bill Abner |work=GameShark |date=2009-02-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090221140628/http://www.gameshark.com/features/569/Blood-Bowl-Q%26A-with-Cyanide-CEO-Patrick-Pligersdorffer.htm |archivedate=2009-02-21 |df= }} The game has both [[real-time strategy|real-time]] and [[turn-based strategy]] modes.{{cite journal |last=Scott |first=Ryan |date=March 2008 |title=Football Slayer |journal=[[Games for Windows: The Official Magazine]] |issue=16 |pages=32}} Players may choose to play the game in either mode. The Special Play cards are not included in the main game. During the main career mode, the player must start from scratch and build a team; the career mode can go on ''ad infinitum''.{{cite web |url=http://www.gameshark.com/features/574/Blood-Bowl-Q&A-Part-II-Community-Questions.htm |title=Blood Bowl Q&A Part II: Community Questions Answered |author=Bill Abner |work=GameShark |date=2009-03-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090304203939/http://www.gameshark.com/features/574/Blood-Bowl-Q%26A-Part-II-Community-Questions.htm |archivedate=2009-03-04 |df= }} As the team goes up in ranking on the tournament ladder, a player will sign better players for their roster. If one or several of the roster players are injured or killed during a match, the player needs to replace them for one or several of the next matches until they are ready to go back to the field. If the player lacks money to heal them, they will still be able to play the injured player, but the chances that player is killed increases. Roster players take part in tournaments, where they gain experience and level up. The player can assign skill points to buy new abilities that will affect the player's performance, such as improving their dice rolls, have a second chance on a bad roll, and other bonuses along those lines. Leagues are completely customizable: there are 25 elements can be edited by the user, such as teams, races, players, and championship rules. Players may also set up online tournaments with others in the online community, which also allows players to gain experience as with the single player mode. Tournaments may have a minimum of four participants, and a maximum of 24; none of the teams may be AI-controlled. A player may play with a solo franchise team online, but may not use it in online tournaments or leagues. Players may not switch between RTS and turn-based modes mid-tournament. Players may create custom logos for their teams. The Nintendo DS and PlayStation Portable versions lack career league play and customization options. Multiplayer involves turn-based [[Hotseat (multiplayer mode)|hotseat]] gameplay on the handheld versions, though the PSP version also includes wireless multiplayer.
The first release on both DS and PSP showed significant functional issues that prevented players to complete career mode as their data files were corrupted after a few hours of game play. A replacement service has since been provided to owners of the PSP version.Official Blood Bowl [https://web.archive.org/web/20110708215829/http://www.cyanide-studio.com/forumBB/viewtopic.php?f=25&t=4494 video game forum]. The Xbox version also suffered issues, such as in-game players not keeping experience they gained during games, making league play useless.http://forum.bloodbowl-game.com/viewtopic.php?f=11&t=952 The Xbox version was also dropped after the original version of the game. ==Expansions== [[File:Bloodbowl ds.jpg|right|thumb|French DS version.]] In October 2009 Cyanide Studios announced a free expansion containing the [[Dark Elves (Warhammer)|Dark Elves]] race.{{cite web|url=http://www.bloodbowl-game.com/index.php?rub=news-info&id=114 |title=The Dark Elves: soon available, for Free! |publisher=[[Cyanide (Studio)|Cyanide]] |work=Press Release |date=2009-10-23 |accessdate=2009-11-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091026143248/http://www.bloodbowl-game.com/index.php?rub=news-info&id=114 |archivedate=October 26, 2009 }} The Update was released on November 20, 2009{{cite web|url=http://bloodbowl-game.com/index.php?rub=news-info&id=118|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091124083355/http://bloodbowl-game.com/index.php?rub=news-info&id=118|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2009-11-24|title=Dark Elves: the free Add-on and the Video available now!|publisher=[[Cyanide (Studio)|Cyanide]]|work=Press Release|date=2009-11-19|accessdate=2009-11-22|df=}} as a free download and as an in-store release in Europe with a strategy guide. A DLC featuring Dark Elves was released along with a title update for Xbox 360, but, while free on the PC, Microsoft chose to charge players for them on the Xbox 360.{{cite web|url=http://www.cyanide-studio.com/forumBB/viewtopic.php?f%3D4%26t%3D14433%26p%3D214649%26hilit%3Dxbox+360+update#p214649 |accessdate=February 6, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110708215907/http://www.cyanide-studio.com/forumBB/viewtopic.php?f=4&t=14433&p=214649&hilit=xbox+360+update |title=Xbox 360 update|archivedate=July 8, 2011 }} Despite being approved in North America, the Xbox title update was not approved in the EMEA territories. In April 2010, Cyanide announced the next version of the game, ''Blood Bowl: Legendary Edition'' would be released in November 2010, with 11 new teams (Amazon, Elf, Halfling, High Elf, Khemri, Necromantic, Norse, Nurgle, Ogre, Undead, and Vampire), and added bug and rules fixes,.http://kotaku.com/5508157/blood-bowl-goes-legendary-with-twelve-new-teams BB:LE is based on the current [[Blood Bowl#Living Rulebook|CRP]] rule set, and contains 21 of the 24 BBRC (Blood Bowl Rules Committee) official rosters. The missing races are [[Chaos Dwarfs]], Chaos Pact and Slann. In May 2012, Cyanide and Focus announced the next version of the game, ''Blood Bowl: Chaos Edition'' would be released, with 3 new teams (2 from the rules - Chaos Dwarves and Underworld, and a third made completely up by them - Daemons of Khorne), 2 additional star players and a new stadium.(Note: Two teams were still left out of the game: Chaos Pact and Slann).http://forum.bloodbowl-game.com/viewtopic.php?f=4&t=1258 Cyanide Studios have also released an adaptation of [[Dungeonbowl]] in the same year.{{cite web|url=http://www.cyanide-studio.com/games/dungeonbowl/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-11-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131221144140/http://cyanide-studio.com/games/dungeonbowl/ |archivedate=2013-12-21 |df= }} A sequel, ''[[Blood Bowl 2]]'', was released in September 2015.{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2014/12/04/blood-bowl-2-coming-to-pc-ps4-and-xbox-one|title=Blood Bowl 2 coming to PC, PS4 and Xbox One|work=[[IGN]]|author=Chloi Rad|date=2014-12-04|accessdate=2015-01-14}} ==Development== [[File:BloodBowl.jpg|left|thumb|Two players engaging in battle.]] [[Cyanide (Studio)|Cyanide]] created a similar title, ''[[Chaos League]]'', in 2004. The similarity between ''Chaos League'' and Games Workshop's ''Blood Bowl'' led to a [[lawsuit]], which was settled out of court. One of the terms of the settlement was that Cyanide would receive a [[intellectual property license|license]] to develop a new title using the official ''Blood Bowl'' property. In August 2007, [[Cyanide (Studio)|Cyanide]] announced that a new game for [[Microsoft Windows]] computers would be developed, due to be released in 2008.{{cite web| last = Sinclair | first = Brendan | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Blood Bowl Blitzes | work = [[GameSpot]] | publisher = [[GameSpot]] | date = 2007-11-16 | url = http://www.gamespot.com/news/618067.html | doi = | accessdate = 2007-11-16 }} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}} On November 14, 2007, the [[Nintendo DS]], [[PlayStation Portable]], and [[Xbox 360]] versions were announced.{{cite web| last = Dobson | first = Jason | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Cyanide confirms Blood Bowl for Xbox 360, PSP, DS | work = [[Joystiq]] | publisher = [[Joystiq]] | date = 2007-11-13 | url = http://www.joystiq.com/2007/11/14/cyanide-confirms-blood-bowl-for-xbox-360-psp-ds | format = | doi = | accessdate = 2007-11-13 }} It was originally believed the game would be on [[Xbox Live Arcade]], but it was revealed to be a store release title. A limited playable version of the game was demonstrated at the Blood Bowl Grand Tournament in [[Nottingham]] over the weekend of the May 10, 2008. On December 18, 2008 it was announced on the Cyanide Blood Bowl forum by a Focus employee that the release date had been pushed back to Q2 2009 (June).{{cite web|title=Release date, new site |publisher=[[Cyanide (Studio)|Cyanide]] |url=http://www.cyanide-studio.com/forumBB/viewtopic.php?f=4&t=105 |accessdate=2008-12-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090203070421/http://www.cyanide-studio.com/forumBB/viewtopic.php?f=4&t=105 |archivedate=February 3, 2009 }} The PC version was made available for digital download on June 26, 2009. On June 25, 2008, a trailer was released featuring the opening cinematic and some gameplay.[http://www.bloodbowl-game.com/news/news.php?id=5&lang=en Blood Bowl trailer] Cyanide Studios received permission from Games Workshop to include a real-time mode in the game, providing the developer strictly adhered to the Living Rulebook 5.0's rules; it was Cyanide's success with ''Chaos League'' that gave Games Workshop the confidence to allow them to adapt the rules to real-time gameplay. ===Digital Rights Management=== The PC version of Blood Bowl has [[SecuROM]] [[digital rights management]] technology. [[SecuROM]] exists in both the DVD retail box release and the digital download releases, including digital download distributions from both [[Steam (software)|Steam]] and [[Impulse (content delivery)|Impulse]] content delivery services.{{cite web |title=Blood Bowl Dark Elves Edition on Steam |publisher=[[Steam (software)|Steam]] |url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/11170/ |accessdate=2010-06-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100606053317/http://store.steampowered.com/app/11170 |archivedate=2010-06-06 |df= }}{{cite web| title = Impulse Driven : Blood Bowl - Dark Elves Edition | publisher = [[Impulse (content delivery)|Impulse]] | url = http://www.impulsedriven.com/bloodbowl | accessdate = 2010-06-07}} An activation code is provided with the game, and there is a specific uninstallation program installed which can be used to revoke the licence for further use. ==Reception== ''Blood Bowl'' was better received on the PC than on consoles. The PC version has online options that the Xbox 360 lacks, and the DS and PSP versions lack any sort of career mode. On the PC, the game scored a [[Metacritic]] average of 72%. On Xbox 360 and PSP it only managed a 61% average, and on Nintendo DS a 52%. GameZone's Steven Hopper gave the Xbox 360 version a 6.5/10, saying "Blood Bowl is a missed opportunity as evidenced by the potential of the source on which it's based. If you really want to get into the depth and fun of Blood Bowl, you're better off checking out the board game."{{cite web |url=http://xbox360.gamezone.com/gzreviews/r1288.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-02-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100227083403/http://xbox360.gamezone.com/gzreviews/r1288.htm |archivedate=2010-02-27 |df= }} GameZone IT Reviews pointed out that on the Xbox 360, ''Blood Bowl'' had a "flaccid and pointless-seeming real-time mode, rough presentation, [and] a lack of online options compared to the PC."{{cite web |url=http://www.itreviews.co.uk/games/g651.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-03-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101115233052/http://www.itreviews.co.uk/games/g651.htm |archivedate=2010-11-15 |df= }} IT Reviews Of the PC version, PC Powerplay magazine commented that: "Despite some presentation concerns the rest of what was on offer during this match was truly thrilling." PC Gamer magazine also agreed, saying: "If you can penetrate the mysteries of its boardgame-based rules, Blood Bowl can offer true barbaric happiness." ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== *[http://www.bloodbowl-game.com/ Official site] {{Games Workshop}} {{Cyanide}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Blood Bowl (2009 Video Game)}} [[Category:2009 video games]] [[Category:Fantasy sports video games]] [[Category:Sports management video games]] [[Category:Warhammer Fantasy video games]] [[Category:Video games developed in France]] [[Category:Windows games]] [[Category:Xbox 360 games]] [[Category:Nintendo DS games]] [[Category:PlayStation Portable games]] [[Category:IOS games]] [[Category:Multiplayer and single-player video games]]

revision.text:
The '''Bolo bat''' was a child's [[toy]] popular in the 1930s through the 1960s. It consisted of a round wooden paddle-like bat with a handle, not unlike a [[ping-pong paddle]], attached to the center of which was a piece of elastic band about three feet long. Attached to end of the elastic band was a rubber ball about an inch in [[diameter]].<ref>{{cite web | title =Pop Bottles | url=http://www.umanitoba.ca/cm/cmarchive/vol15no6/popbottles.html | accessdate = 2009-10-09}}</ref>
The child would bat the ball as far as the elastic would allow it to travel. When it reached the furthest distance from the bat that the elastic would allow, it sprang back at the bat where it was hit again and again. The object of the game was to see how many times the child could hit the ball and have it return and be hit again. Children competed against themselves and others for the greatest number of successful hits.
This is possibly the same thing as a [[paddle ball]].
==References== {{Reflist}} {{Toy-stub}}

The album was released on April 8, 2016, by [[Entertainment One Music]].{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/book-of-shadows-ii/id1083148121 |title=Book of Shadows II by Zakk Wylde on iTunes |publisher=Itunes.apple.com |date=1967-01-14 |accessdate=2016-03-11}}{{cite web|url=http://loudwire.com/zakk-wylde-book-of-shadows-ii-album-details-new-song/ |title=Zakk Wylde Releases 'Book of Shadows II' Details + New Song |publisher=Loudwire.com |date=2016-02-25 |accessdate=2016-03-11}} ==Track listing== {{Track listing | total_length = | title1 = Autumn Changes | note1 = | length1 = 5:14 | title2 = Tears of December | note2 = | length2 = 3:35 | title3 = Lay Me Down | note3 = | length3 = 6:06 | title4 = Lost Prayer | note4 = | length4 = 4:27 | title5 = Darkest Hour | note5 = | length5 = 5:05 | title6 = The Levee | note6 = | length6 = 5:47 | title7 = Eyes of Burden | note7 = | length7 = 3:43 | title8 = Forgotten Memory | note8 = | length8 = 3:49 | title9 = Yesterday's Tears | note9 = | length9 = 4:15 | title10 = Harbors of Pity | note10 = | length10 = 4:10 | title11 = Sorrowed Regrets | note11 = | length11 = 5:46 | title12 = Useless Apologies | note12 = | length12 = 3:38 | title13 = Sleeping Dogs | note13 = featuring [[Corey Taylor]] | length13 = 4:36 | title14 = The King | note14 = | length14 = 4:42 }} ==Charts== {| class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center" |- ! scope="col"| Chart (2016) ! scope="col"| Peak

{{italic title}} '''''CBS Workshop''''', aka ''CBS Repertoire Workshop'' is an hour-long dramatic television anthology series that was produced by and aired on [[CBS]] mid-day on Sundays in 1960. There were a total of twenty-five episodes with guest stars that included [[Maureen Stapleton]], [[Raul Davila]], <ref> [https://www.imdb.com/title/tt6249208/?ref_=nm_flmg_msdp_10 ''CBS Repertoire Workshop - "Feliz Borinquen"'' Raul Davila introducer on www.imdb.com]</ref> <ref> [https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0246299/?ref_=ttfc_fc_cl_t3 Raul Davila on www.imdb.com]</ref> [[Ossie Davis]], [[Larry Hagman]], [[Fritz Weaver]], and [[Andrew Prine]]. Collaborators from the realm of opera included the conductor [[Alfredo Antonini]] and the soprano [[Martina Arroyo]] <ref>[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt6249208/?ref_=nm_flmg_msdp_10 ''CBS Repertoire Workshop - "Feliz Borinquen"'' Martina Arroyo soprano, Alfredo Antonini conductor]</ref> <ref> [https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1711009/?ref_=ttfc_fc_cl_t1 Martina Arroyo on www.imdb.com]</ref> <ref> [https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0031350/?ref_=ttfc_fc_cr2 Alfredo Antonini on www.imdb.com]</ref> Contributors from the world of modern American dance included [[Alwin Nikolais]], [[Murray Louis]] and [[Ruth Page (ballerina)|Ruth Page]] <ref> "Television and the Performing Arts - A Handbook and Reference Guide to American Cultural Programming" Rose, Brain G. Greenwood Press, New York, 1986, P. 43. {{ISBN|0-313-24159-7}} [https://books.google.com/books?id=0bMi22WDcvoC&pg=PA43&dq=CBS+Repertoire+Workshop&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwichP2s6YLYAhUqDcAKHTxYBHA4ChDoAQg6MAU#v=onepage&q=CBS%20Repertoire%20Workshop&f=false ''Television and the Performing Arts - A Handbook and Reference Guide to American Cultural Programing'' - ''CBS Repertoire Workshop'' on www.books.google.com]</ref> <ref> [https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1310938/?ref_=ttfc_fc_cr17 Ruth Page on www.imdb.com]</ref> <ref> [http://www.chicagofilmarchives.org/collections/index.php/Detail/Object/Show/object_id/8745 ''Repertoire Workshop From Chicago - Carmen and Jose'' - featuring The Ruth Page Ballet on the www.chicagofilmarchives.org]</ref>
Among its writers were [[Lewis John Carlino]] and [[Robert Herridge]].
==References== <references/>
==External links== *{{IMDb title|id=0380857|title=CBS Repertoire Workshop}} *[http://ctva.biz/US/Anthology/CBSWorkshop_1960.htm ''CBS Workshop'' at CVTA]

{{Orphan|date=June 2016}}
{{Infobox person | name = Cam Kirk | image = Cam Kirk.jpg | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1989|2|27}} | birth_place = Maryland | occupation = Photographer & Videographer | networth = | spouse = | children = | residence = [[Atlanta, Georgia]] | alma_mater = Morehouse College | website = {{URL|thecamkirk.com}} | signature = | parents = }}
Cameron '''"Cam Kirk"''' Kirkland (born February 27, 1989), is a photographer and videographer. Cam Kirk has worked with and produced work for many hip hop artists and entertainers such as [[Young Jeezy]], [[T.I.]], [[Monica (singer)|Monica]], [[2 Chainz]], [[Mike Will Made It]], [[Estelle (musician)|Estelle]], [[Schoolboy Q]], [[Future (rapper)|Future]], [[Gucci Mane]], DC Young Fly, [[Young Dolph]], [[Yo Gotti]], [[DJ Khaled]] and many more.<ref name="complex.com">{{Cite web|title = Portfolio Review: Cam Kirk Captures Images of the Rap World|url = http://www.complex.com/style/2014/04/portfolio-review-cam-kirk/|accessdate = 2015-10-06}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Portfolio Review: Cam Kirk Captures Images of the Rap World - ''Gucci Mane Shooting''|url = http://www.complex.com/style/2014/04/portfolio-review-cam-kirk/gucci-mane-shooting|accessdate = 2015-10-06}}</ref>
== Early life and education == Cam Kirk was born and raised in [[Prince George's County, Maryland|Prince George’s County, Maryland]] with his three siblings and parents. There he attended Bishop McNamara High School. During his youth, Cam Kirk was inspired by his father's passion for photography as he allowed Kirk to assist him with his projects. After graduating high school in 2007, Cam Kirk moved to Atlanta, Georgia. Upon arriving to Atlanta, Cam Kirk attended [[Morehouse College]] where he majored in Business Marketing. While in Atlanta, Cam Kirk focused on his true passion, photography and videography.<ref name=about>{{Cite web|title = About|url = http://thecamkirk.com/about/|accessdate = 2015-10-06}}</ref>
== Career ==
Cam Kirk's work has been published in a variety of magazines which include: [[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard Magazine]], [[XXL (magazine)|XXL]], [[The Source (magazine)|The Source]], [[The Fader]] Magazine, [[Spin (magazine)|Spin Magazine]], [[MTV]], [[BuzzFeed]], [[Complex (magazine)|Complex Magazine]], Pitchfork, [[Vice (magazine)|Vice Magazine]], [[Revolt (TV network)|Revolt TV]], [[Black Entertainment Television (BET)|BET]] & More.<ref name=about/><ref name="complex.com"/><ref>{{Cite web|title = Framing New Atlanta: Photographer Cam Kirk Captures the City's Rap Scene Before It Happens {{!}} NOISEY|url = http://noisey.vice.com/blog/cam-kirk-photographer-atlanta-profile|accessdate = 2015-10-06}}</ref><ref name="vibe.com">{{Cite web|title = Cam Kirk Captures The Spirit Of The Trap God With East Atlanta Exhibit For Gucci Mane {{!}} Vibe|url = http://www.vibe.com/2015/06/cam-kirk-trap-god-exhibit-interview/|accessdate = 2015-10-06}}</ref> [[Complex (magazine)|Complex Magazine]] named Cam Kirk as one of 15 photographers that every rap fan should know. [[Hypebeast]] has also named him Hip Hop's Most Trusted Photographer.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://hypebeast.com/2017/6/cam-kirk-hip-hop-photographer-interview|title=Cam Kirk Is Hip-Hop's Most Trusted Photographer, Now He's Teaching Everything He's Learned|work=HYPEBEAST|access-date=2017-06-04|language=en}}</ref> In 2016, Atlanta's Largest Radio Station Hot 107.9 invited Cam Kirk as their first ever photographer to be featured and interviewed on the air. In 2017, Cam Kirk was also included in [[DeLeón Tequila|DeLeon Tequila]]'s list of 100 Influencers Taking it to the Next Level.
== Exhibitions ==
=== Trap God ===
In an effort to bridge the gap between Art and Hip Hop, Cam Kirk pioneered the first Trap House photography exhibit, entitled ''"Trap God"''. ''Trap God'' was a photography exhibit featuring never before seen photographs of rapper [[Gucci Mane]]. The exhibit took place in an abandoned church in East Atlanta Village and presented live aspects as a point of innovation and artistry in the exhibit. The live aspects were actual actors posed as Trap Girls, a Trap Queen, a gun & bible wielding Pastor, and much more. The exhibit concluded with rapper [[Young Thug]] shooting his music video for the song entitled [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=N4gmGYhr-7k "Again"] at the event. ''The Trap God Exhibit'' received national attention and was featured in many major magazines.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Young Thug Visits ‘Trap God’ Exhibit to Shoot Gucci Mane-Assisted Cut "Again"|url = http://boi-1da.net/2015/08/17/young-thug-visits-trap-god-exhibit-to-shoot-gucci-mane-assisted-cut-again/|website = Boi-1da.net|accessdate = 2015-10-06}}</ref><ref name="vibe.com"/>
=== Day 4 Billboard Exhibit === Cam Kirk’s ''"Day 4 Exhibit"'' launched in Atlanta, Georgia, on April 19, 2016. The exhibit has been updated monthly with unreleased photos of influential artists. The exhibit began by being funded through a Kick Starter campaign giving fans of hip hop and photography alike the opportunity to contribute and be a part of the exhibit directly. The exhibit has spanned to various artists and locations, including Miami, FL.
The first billboard in the ''Day 4 Exhibit'' was dedicated to the late, [[Bankroll Fresh]]. Cam Kirk linked with friends and super producers [[Metro Boomin]], [[Sonny Digital]] and [[Southside (record producer)|Southside]] to dedicate a billboard to a fallen friend. Thus far, Cam Kirk has displayed [[Metro Boomin]], [[21 Savage]], [[Sonny Digital]], [[Lil Yachty]], [[Rich the Kid|Rich The Kid]], [[Migos|The Migos]], Trouble, DC Young Fly, [[6LACK|6lack]] and displayed clothing of the London based clothing brand Marbek.
=== Art Basel === [[Art Basel]] stages art shows for modern and contemporary art and is sited annually in Basel,Switzerland, Miami Beach, Florida and Hong Kong, Japan. Each show has participating galleries, exhibition sectors, artworks and parallel programming produced in collaboration with the host city's local institutions.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Art Basel 2014 Guide|url = http://normanow.com/events/art-basel-2014-guide/|accessdate = 2015-10-06}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Hip-Hop Through His Lens: Atlanta Photographer, Cam Kirk, Set To Release Photo Book [Details]|url = http://thatsenuff.com/2015/01/11/hip-hop-through-his-lens-atlanta-photographer-cam-kirk-set-to-release-photo-book-details/|website = THATSENUFF.COM|accessdate = 2015-10-06}}</ref> December 2016, Cam Kirk participated in [[Art basel miami|Art Basel Miami]] with a collaboration for an event entitled ''inFocus. Hip Hop Through The Lens of Photography'' event Curated by [[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard Magazine]] and [[1800 Tequila]], alongside a few other photographers. Cam Kirk also brought his ''Day 4 Billboard Exhibit'' to Miami displaying [[Migos|the Migos]].
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links ==
* http://www.complex.com/style/2014/04/portfolio-review-cam-kirk/ * http://www.complex.com/style/2015/01/hip-hop-photographer-cam-kirk-releases-first-photo-book * http://greenlabel.com/sound/cam-kirk-digging-through-the-greats/ * http://www.thefader.com/2015/04/17/rodeo-tour-photos-travis-scott-young-thug-cam-kirk-tour-diary * http://www.hotnewhiphop.com/gucci-mane-photo-exhibition-to-take-place-in-atlanta-church-news.15574.html * http://www.vibe.com/2015/06/cam-kirk-trap-god-exhibit-interview/ * http://www.xxlmag.com/news/2015/05/photographer-cam-kirk-gucci-mane-exhibit/ * http://www.complex.com/style/2015/01/hip-hop-photographer-cam-kirk-releases-first-photo-book * http://massappeal.com/photographer-cam-kirk-pays-homage-to-gucci-mane-with-trap-god-exhibition/ * http://meettheculture.com/tag/cam-kirk/ * http://noisey.vice.com/blog/cam-kirk-photographer-atlanta-profile * http://thecamkirk.com/about/ * http://thatsenuff.com/2015/01/11/hip-hop-through-his-lens-atlanta-photographer-cam-kirk-set-to-release-photo-book-details/ * https://web.archive.org/web/20151006095224/https://roundtown.com/event/3121027/SONNY-DIGITAL-FRIENDS-CAM-KIRK-PHOTO-POP-UP-GALLERY-Miami-FL
