'''Television in [[Jordan]]''' is dominated by pan-Arab satellite, with terrestrial accounting for 16% of TV households in the country. There are 29 free-to-air satellite channels headquartered in Jordan. Pay-TV penetration is low, estimated at 4% in 2011.<ref name=amo12>{{cite web|title=Arab Media Outlook 2011-2015|url=http://www.arabmediaforum.ae/userfiles/EnglishAMO.pdf|page=184|year=2012}}</ref>
The state broadcaster is the [[Jordan Radio and Television Corporation]], which operates a domestic channel and broadcasts internationally via the Jordan Satellite channel.
The independent local channel [[Roya TV]] broadcasts local news, dramas and a variety of political, social and economic programmes.<ref name="amo12"/>
==List of major channels==
The number of satellite television channels broadcasting from Jordan reached 45 at the end of 2015.<ref>{{ cite web|url=http://www.jordantimes.com/news/local/45-satellite-tv-channels-broadcast-jordan}}</ref> However, here is a list of the major Jordanian TV channels:
* [[Jordan Radio and Television Corporation|JRTV]] *Jordan Series Channel *Jordan News TV *Alhakeka *Nourmina Satellite Channel *[[Roya TV]] *Toyor al Jannah *Toyor baby *Amman ONE *GOTV SPORTS *Roya sports *Jordan Sports *[[Amman TV]] *Josat *Noursat jordan *[[Al Mamlaka TV Channel]]
==References== {{reflist}}

{{Infobox film | name = The Barrier | image = The Barrier 1990 poster.jpg | image_size = | border = | alt = | caption = A 1990 theatrical poster | director = [[Bassam Al-Thawadi]] | producer = Bassam Al-Thawadi | writer = Ameen Salih (screenplay),Ali Al Sharqawi (dialogue) | screenplay = Ameen Salih | story = | based on = <!-- {{based on|title of the original work|writer of the original work}} --> | narrator = | starring = *Ebrahim Bahar * Rashed Al-Hassan * Mariam Ziman | music = Hani Shnudah | cinematography = Hassan Abdulkareem | editing = Yousif Al Malakh | studio = | distributor = | released = {{Film date|1990|6|6|Bahrain}} | runtime = 97 minutes | country = [[Bahrain]] | language = Arabic | budget = $150,000 (estimated) | gross = }} '''The Barrier''' (transliterated: ''Al Hajiz'') is a 1990 [[Bahrain]]i [[Arabic language]] [[drama film]] directed and produced by [[Bassam Al-Thawadi]], starring Ebrahim Bahar, Rashed Al-Hassan and Mariam Ziman. The screenplay was written by Ameen Salih. The film is widely regarded as being the first [[feature film]] produced in Bahrain.<ref name=GW>{{cite news|title=A Bahraini's passion for films|url=http://www.gulfweekly.com/Articles.aspx?articleid=16419|accessdate=21 June 2012|newspaper=Gulf Weekly|date=August 8, 2007}}</ref>
==Summary== The movie deals with social and emotional barriers imposed upon individuals by [[society]] and also with those that the individual imposes upon himself. The characters in the movie lack the ability to communicate with each other and therefore, fail to understand their own emotions. Hence, they fail to maintain healthy [[Interpersonal relationship|relationship]]s with each other because of the lack of love amongst them. This failure is attributed to the surrounding environment that does not allow for healthy relationships to grow and prosper.<ref>{{cite web|title=IMDB profile|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0390072/|accessdate=21 June 2012}}</ref>
==Cast== *Ebrahim Bahar as Mustafa *Rashed Al-Hassan as Hassan *Mariam Ziman as Fatima *Gahtan Al-Gahtani as Mohammed *Latifa Mujren as the Mother *Abdulrahman Barakat as the Father *Soad Ali as Huda *Anwar Ahmed as Gang man *Norah Yousif as the Neighbor *Amina Hussain as Street Girl

{{Infobox comic book title | title=The Dark Knight Strikes Again | image=BatmanDK2.jpg | caption=Cover of the trade paperback ''Batman: The Dark Knight Strikes Again''. | schedule=Monthly | format= | limited=y | publisher=[[DC Comics]] | date=December 2001 – July 2002 | issues=3 | main_char_team=[[Batman (Dark Knight Universe)|Batman]]

[[Carrie Kelley|Catgirl]]
[[Lex Luthor]]
[[Brainiac (character)|Brainiac]]

Lynn Varley
Bob Kane
Bill Finger | subcat=Batman | limsub=DC Comics | sort=Dark Knight Strikes Again | addpubcat1 = Elseworlds titles }} '''''Batman: The Dark Knight Strikes Again''''', also known as '''''DK2''''', is a 2001-2002 [[DC Comics]] three-issue [[Limited series (comics)|limited series]] comic book written and illustrated by [[Frank Miller (comics)|Frank Miller]] and colored by [[Lynn Varley]]. The series is a sequel to Miller's 1986 miniseries ''[[The Dark Knight Returns]]''. It tells the story of an aged [[Batman (Dark Knight Universe)|Bruce Wayne]] who returns from three years in hiding, training his followers and instigating a rebellion against [[Lex Luthor]]'s dictatorial rule over the United States. The series features an [[ensemble cast]] of superheroes including [[Carrie Kelley|Catgirl]], [[Superman]], [[Wonder Woman]], [[Plastic Man]], [[Flash (Barry Allen)|The Flash]], and [[Atom (Ray Palmer)|the Atom]]. == Overview == The series was originally published as a three-issue limited series published by DC Comics between November 2001 and July 2002. It has since been published as hardcover and paperback one-volume editions and as the [[DC Comics Absolute Edition|''Absolute Dark Knight'']] edition with ''The Dark Knight Returns''. Like its predecessor, this story takes place in a timeline that is not considered canonical in the current DC Comics continuity.{{cite web |url = http://comics.ign.com/articles/685/685820p1.html |last = Sanderson |first = Peter |title = Comics in Context #119: All-Star Bats | work = [[IGN|IGN Entertainment, Inc.]]|date = February 6, 2006|accessdate = April 24, 2013}} ==Synopsis== [[Image:DarkKnightStrikesAgain1.jpg|right|thumb|Frank Miller's cover to ''The Dark Knight Strikes Again'' #1.]] After going underground, Batman (Bruce Wayne) and his young sidekick Catgirl (formerly [[Carrie Kelley]]{{mdash}}[[Robin (comics)|Robin]]) train an army of "Batboys" (the former Mutants and other recruits) to save the world from a police dictatorship led by [[Lex Luthor]]. In a series of raids on government facilities, Batman's soldiers release other superheroes{{mdash}}including [[Atom (Ray Palmer)|Atom]], [[Flash (Barry Allen)|Flash]] and [[Plastic Man]]{{mdash}}from captivity. [[Elongated Man]] is recruited and [[Green Arrow]] is already working with Batman. [[Superman]], [[Wonder Woman]], and [[Captain Marvel (DC Comics)|Captain Marvel]] have been forced to work for the US government, as their loved ones are being held hostage. Superman is ordered by "[[Prez (comics)|President Rickard]]" (a computer-generated front for Lex Luthor and [[Brainiac (character)|Brainiac]]) to stop Batman. He confronts Wayne at the [[Batcave]], but Batman and the other superheroes defeat him. Meanwhile, Batman's raids have been noticed by the media. After being banned for years, the freed superheroes have recaptured the public imagination and have become a fad among the youth. At a pop concert by "The Superchix", Batman and the other heroes make a public appearance urging their fans to rebel against the oppressive government. During this time, rogue vigilante [[Question (comics)|Question]] spies on Luthor's plans and types a journal to record the misdeeds of those in power. Question tries to convince the [[Martian Manhunter]]{{mdash}}now an aged, bitter, near-powerless figure with his mind filled with Luthor's nanotechnology{{mdash}}to stand up against Superman and the government. Question and Martian Manhunter are attacked by a mysterious man resembling [[Joker (comics)|the Joker]], who is seemingly invulnerable to injury. Martian Manhunter sacrifices his life and Question is rescued by Green Arrow. The mysterious man escapes to kill other superheroes including [[Guardian (DC Comics)|Guardian]] and [[Creeper (comics)|Creeper]], stealing their costumes and wearing them. An extraterrestrial monster lands in [[Metropolis (comics)|Metropolis]] and begins to destroy the city. Batman is convinced that it is an attempt to lure him and his allies out of hiding and does not respond, dismissing Flash's appeal that they are supposed to save lives. Batman's opinion is that it is too risky to save the lives of the populace. Superman and Captain Marvel fight the monster which is Brainiac, who coerces Superman into defeat using the bottled Kryptonian city of [[Kandor (comics)|Kandor]] as leverage, to crush the people's faith in superheroes. Captain Marvel is killed defending citizens from the carnage but Superman is saved when his daughter Lara appears. She has been carefully hidden since birth but now that the government knows she exists, they demand that she be handed over. Deciding that Batman and his methods are the only way, Superman, Wonder Woman and Lara join him. Lara pretends to hand herself over to Brainiac. Atom slips into the bottle and frees the Kandorians, who use their combined heat vision to destroy Brainiac. The superheroes then destroy the dictatorship's power source and incite a revolution. Batman allows himself to be captured and tortured by Luthor to learn his plans. Luthor has launched satellites to destroy most of the world's population, leaving him with a more manageable number of people. The Green Lantern, who has turned into pure will, returns from space and destroys Luthor's satellites. Luthor is in turn killed by the son of [[Hawkman]]. Returning to the Batcave, Batman is contacted by Carrie, who is being attacked by the Joker-like man and now wearing a Robin costume. Batman arrives and recognizes the man as [[Dick Grayson]], the first Robin who Batman fired long ago. Grayson has been genetically altered to have a powerful healing factor and shape-shifting ability, but is criminally insane. As Batman and Grayson contemptuously recall their bleak history together, Batman drops him through a trapdoor into a miles-deep crevasse filled with lava, while Elongated Man rescues Carrie. Grayson clings onto a ledge, climbs out of the chasm and faces Batman. When Grayson remains virtually unharmed by everything Batman throws at him, Batman hurls himself and Grayson into the chasm. Grayson falls into the lava and is disintegrated. Superman rescues Batman at the last minute as the Batcave explodes, and takes him to Carrie in the Batmobile. ==Characters== * '''[[Batman (Dark Knight Universe)|Batman]]'''{{mdash}}Bruce Wayne's alter ego who is 58 years old and faked his death three years ago and continues to operate secretly as Batman. He leads a rebellion against the corrupt U.S. government headed by Lex Luthor. Batman is a skilled and controversial strategist who makes decisions which result in deaths, which he considers necessary for the defeat of his enemies. * '''[[Carrie Kelley|Catgirl]]'''{{mdash}}Carrie Kelley, formerly Robin, is Batman's second-in-command. * '''[[Lex Luthor]]'''{{mdash}}the main antagonist of ''The Dark Knight Strikes Again''. Luthor heads the U.S. government and uses a hologram of what the people think is the President as a figurehead. He controls powerful superheroes{{mdash}}including Superman, Captain Marvel and Wonder Woman{{mdash}}by holding their loved ones hostage. * '''[[Brainiac (character)|Brainiac]]'''{{mdash}}provides Luthor with the means to control the U.S., and hence the world. * '''[[Superman]]'''{{mdash}}controlled by Luthor, who is holding the miniaturized city of Kandor hostage. Encouraged by his daughter and Batman, Superman finally fights back and breaks his own vow not to kill. * '''[[Wonder Woman]]'''{{mdash}}the youthful Queen of the Amazons who has a daughter with Superman. * '''Lara'''{{mdash}}The daughter of Superman and Wonder Woman who has the powers of a Kryptonian and the warrior attitude of an Amazon. She has a poor opinion of people less powerful than herself and tries to persuade Superman to rise above the humans and possibly take over the world. * '''[[Captain Marvel (DC Comics)|Captain Marvel]]'''{{mdash}}now an old man, he still stands by Superman and Wonder Woman. Captain Marvel is limited in his abilities because Luthor holds his sister [[Mary Marvel|Mary]] hostage. He reveals that he and Billy Batson were two separate beings who switched places, and that Billy (who had always been sickly) had died around 8 years ago. This rendered him incapable of just switching out to recuperate because there would be no one to call him back * '''"The Joker"/[[Alternative versions of Robin#The Dark Knight Universe Robins|Dick Grayson]]'''{{mdash}}The original Robin, Grayson is the final antagonist of the story. Having been emotionally abused by Batman and sacked years before for "cowardice and incompetence", Grayson has submitted himself to radical gene therapy by Luthor and other villains. He has gained a powerful healing factor and shape-shifting ability, but was driven criminally insane. For most of the story, Grayson takes on the appearance of the Joker and the costumes of members of the [[Legion of Super-Heroes]]. His victims include [[Martian Manhunter]], [[Creeper (comics)|Creeper]], [[Guardian (DC Comics)|the Guardian]], and he almost kills Carrie Kelley. * '''[[Atom (Ray Palmer)|Atom]]'''{{mdash}}trapped inside a Petri dish for over two years, Ray Palmer is rescued by Carrie Kelley and becomes one of the first of the old superheroes to join Batman's rebellion. * '''[[Flash (Barry Allen)|The Flash]]'''{{mdash}}coerced by threats to his wife [[Iris West|Iris]], Barry Allen is forced to run in a giant electrical generator before being freed by Carrie Kelley and the Atom. * '''[[Elongated Man]]'''{{mdash}}Ralph Dibny advertises sex drugs on television before joining Batman. * '''[[Plastic Man]]'''{{mdash}}insane and rescued from Arkham Asylum, Eel O'Brian joins Batman's group. * '''The Superchix'''{{mdash}}an all-girl pop/superhero group consisting of a [[Black Canary]] lookalike, Bat Chick and Wonder Chick. * '''[[Green Arrow]]'''{{mdash}}a communist, activist and billionaire with a mechanical arm, Oliver Queen has long been part of Batman's forces. * '''[[Question (comics)|The Question]]'''{{mdash}}fighting for Batman's cause, Vic Sage works mainly alone and tries to recruit the former [[Martian Manhunter]]. He spies on Luthor and his associates, and distrusts technology and [[municipalization]]. * '''[[Martian Manhunter]]'''{{mdash}}a victim of Luthor's [[nanobots]], which have deprived him of most of his powers, J'onn J'onzz has become addicted to alcohol and tobacco. He retains a precognitive sense which he uses to help Question. * '''[[Hal Jordan|Green Lantern]]'''{{mdash}}Hal Jordan now lives with his own alien family in a distant part of the galaxy. He returns to Earth at Batman's request. * '''Hawkboy'''{{mdash}}Hawkman's son who grew up with his sister in the Costa Rican rainforest. When their parents are killed by a military strike ordered by Luthor, Hawkboy intends to take revenge. * '''[[Saturn Girl]]'''{{mdash}}a young, thirteen-year-old who can see into the future. She adopts the name and outfit of the 31st-century [[Legion of Super-Heroes|Legionnaire]]. * '''[[Prez (comics)|Rick Rickard]]'''{{mdash}}the holographic puppet President of the United States. * U.S. Secretary of State '''[[Sturm, Ruger & Co.|Ruger]]''', '''[[Exxon]]''' and Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff General '''[[Starbucks]]'''{{mdash}}members of Luthor's government. * '''[[Hawk and Dove]]'''{{mdash}}Hank and Don Hall are in their old age. They try to take up the tights again only to not go through with it as they used to argue all the time. * '''[[Bat-Mite]]'''{{mdash}}Batman's old antagonist and co-founder of ''The First Church of The Last Son of Krypton.'', a lunatic fringe movement dedicated to worshipping Superman. * '''[[Big Barda]]'''{{mdash}}a former pornographic actress called Hot Gates. When America descends into chaos, Big Barda declares herself dictator of [[Columbus, Ohio]]. * '''Lana Harper-Lane'''{{mdash}}a television news reporter who is presumed to be the daughter of [[Guardian (DC Comics)|Guardian]] and [[Lois Lane]].{{cite web|url=http://www.thefourthrail.com/reviews/snapjudgments/120301/darkknightstrikesagain1.shtml |first=Randy |last=Lander |title=Dark Knight Strikes Again #1 (Best of the Week!) |work=The Fourth Rail |date=December 3, 2001 |accessdate=December 30, 2010 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20020415050933/http://www.thefourthrail.com/reviews/snapjudgments/120301/darkknightstrikesagain1.shtml |archivedate = April 15, 2002}} ==Critical reception and sales== ''The Dark Knight Strikes Again'' received mixed to negative reviews, with criticism focusing on its artwork, storyline, and character development.{{cite web |url=http://www.infinityplus.co.uk/fantasticfiction/darkknightagain.htm |title=The Dark Knight Strikes Again |first = Claude|last = Lalumière|date = September 21, 2002 |accessdate=August 30, 2012}}{{cite web| url= http://www.jasonsanford.com/review-of-the-dark-knight-strikes-again-by-frank-miller/ |title=Review of The Dark Knight Strikes Again by Frank Miller |first = Jason|last = Sanford |date=2002 |accessdate=June 3, 2018}}{{cite web| url= https://www.star2.com/culture/books/2015/12/02/why-does-everyone-hate-the-dark-knight-strikes-again/ |title=Why does everyone hate The Dark Knight Strikes Again? |first = Michael|last = Cheang |date= December 2, 2015 |accessdate=June 3, 2018}} Claude Lalumière of ''[[The Montreal Gazette]]'' gave the series a mixed review and said, "the script lacks the emotional nuances of its predecessor, and ... the artwork is rushed and garish", and that it "has considerable [[chutzpah]], but its careless execution is regrettable".{{cite web |url=http://www.infinityplus.co.uk/fantasticfiction/darkknightagain.htm |title=The Dark Knight Strikes Again |first = Claude|last = Lalumière|date = September 21, 2002 |accessdate=August 30, 2012}} Roger Sabin of ''[[The Guardian]]'' wrote that the series has "flashes of brilliance{{mdash}}few can control page layouts like Miller{{mdash}}but in general the idea of the ironic superhero seems rather dated."{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2002/dec/15/bestbooksof2002.comics |first = Roger|last = Sabin |title=Take a picture... |date = December 15, 2002 |newspaper=[[The Observer]] |accessdate=August 30, 2012}} Tony Millionaire quoted that "Miller did things for comics just as The Ramones did for music". But it was widely criticized for the use of "adultery that is not suitable for teens who are huge fans of the Dark Knight" The first issue of "''DK2''" ranked #1 in December 2001 with pre-order sales at 174,339.{{cite web| url= http://icv2.com/articles/comics/view/912/top-300-comics-december-2001 |title=Top 300 Comics – December 2001 |work=[[ICv2]] |date=November 28, 2001}} The second issue of ''DK2'' was ranked third in sales for the January 2002 period with pre-order sales of 155,322.{{cite web | url=http://www.icv2.com/articles/news/987.html| title=Top 300 Comics – January 2002 |work=ICv2 |date=January 2, 2002 |accessdate=July 9, 2008}} The final issue of the series had pre-order sales of 171,546 returning to #1 for the month of February 2002.{{cite web |url=http://icv2.com/articles/comics/view/1080/top-300-comics-february-2002 |title=Top 300 Comics – February 2002 |work=ICv2 |date=February 4, 2002}} The comic had an in-store date on July 31 of that same year.https://web.archive.org/web/20020617192723/http://www1.cinescape.com/0/editorial.asp?aff_id=0&this_cat=Comics&action=page&type_id=&cat_id=270363&obj_id=34913 ==Sequel== {{main|The Dark {{Infobox book <!-- |italic title = (see above) --> | name = The Young Flying Fox | image = The Young Flying Fox Wuxia History 1960.jpg | caption = One part of ''The Young Flying Fox'' from the magazine ''Wuxia and History'' | author = [[Jin Yong]] | title_orig = {{noitalics|飛狐外傳}} | translator = | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = Hong Kong | language = Chinese | genre = [[Wuxia]] | publisher = ''Wuxia and History'' | pub_date = 1960 | english_pub_date = | media_type = Print | pages = | isbn = | oclc = | dewey = | congress = | followed_by = [[Fox Volant of the Snowy Mountain]] | wikisource = }} {{Chinese|t=飛狐外傳|s=飞狐外传|p=Fēi Hú Wài Zhuàn|j=Fei1 Wu4 Ngoi6 Zyun6|l=Flying Fox Tales}} '''''The Young Flying Fox'''''<ref name="Hamm2005">{{cite book|last=Hamm|first=John Christopher|title=Paper Swordsmen: Jin Yong And The Modern Chinese Martial Arts Novel|year=2005|publisher=University of Hawaii Press|isbn=978-0-8248-2763-2|page=130}}</ref><ref name="HussLiu2007">{{cite book|first1=Ann|last1=Huss|first2=Jianmei|last2=Liu|title=The Jin Yong Phenomenon: Chinese Martial Arts Fiction and Modern Chinese Literary History|year=2007|publisher=Cambria Press|isbn=978-1-934043-08-0|page=195}}</ref> is a [[wuxia]] novel by [[Jin Yong|Jin Yong (Louis Cha)]]. The novel was first serialised in Hong Kong in 1960<ref>The date conforms to the data published in Chen Zhenhui (陳鎮輝), ''Wuxia Xiaoshuo Xiaoyao Tan'' (武俠小說逍遙談), 2000, Huizhi Publishing Company (匯智出版有限公司), p. 58.</ref> in the magazine ''Wuxia and History'' (武俠與歷史). The novel is a prequel to ''[[Fox Volant of the Snowy Mountain]]'' and was written a year after its literary predecessor.
==Plot== The story is set in the [[Qing dynasty]] during the reign of the [[Qianlong Emperor]] ({{reign}} 1735–1796). The protagonist, Hu Fei, is a young martial artist who was raised by Ping A'si after the death of his father, Hu Yidao. While travelling around the land in search of adventure, Hu Fei encounters Feng Tiannan, a ruthless villain, and wants to kill him to deliver justice for the victims. He also meets a young maiden, Yuan Ziyi, who shows signs of affection towards him. She stops Hu Fei from killing Feng Tiannan each time when he is close to killing Feng.
Based on what Ping A'si told him, Hu Fei believes that Miao Renfeng is responsible for his father's death. He refrains from killing Miao after finding him, because Miao has been tricked by an enemy and temporarily blinded by a deadly poison. He is so impressed with Miao's sense of chivalry that he starts wondering if Ping A'si was mistaken about Miao. He decides to help Miao and journeys to find a cure for his eyes. He meets Cheng Lingsu, an apprentice of a deceased medicine guru known as the "King of Venoms". Hu Fei witnesses Cheng Lingsu defeating her three wicked seniors with her calm and wit. She agrees to help him cure Miao Renfeng's eyes.
When Miao Renfeng regains his sight, he confesses that he did kill Hu Yidao unintentionally several years ago. Hu Fei is filled with sorrow upon hearing the truth and he leaves with Cheng Lingsu. Cheng Lingsu and Hu Fei become sworn siblings. While travelling together, they chance upon an election for a new leader of the ''[[Jianghu|wulin]]'' (martial artists' community) hosted by the general [[Fuk'anggan]]. The election is part of Fuk'anggan's plan to instigate turmoil in the ''wulin'' and keep it under the Qing government's control. Hu Fei and Cheng Lingsu disguise themselves and participate in the event. With help from Yuan Ziyi, the trio combine efforts to expose Fuk'anggan's plot and disrupt the election.
They are attacked by enemies and Hu Fei is poisoned while shielding Cheng Lingsu with his body. Cheng loses her life trying to save Hu and reveals to him before dying that she loves him. Hu is filled with anguish after hearing that. After Cheng's funeral, he meets Yuan Ziyi, who tells him that she had already taken an oath to be a Buddhist nun in her childhood, and hence cannot be together with him even though she loves him. She places her palms together and recites a silent prayer for him before leaving.
==Characters==
===Protagonists=== * '''Hu Fei''' ({{zh|c=胡斐|p=Hú Fěi|j=Wu4 Fei2|labels=no}}) is the protagonist of the novel. * '''Hu Yidao''' ({{zh|c=胡一刀|p=Hú Yīdāo|j=Wu4 Jat1-dou1|labels=no}}) is a forthright and gregarious hero whose skills are legendary. He hopes to resolve the past feuds between the four families that have lasted since their ancestors' time. He is instigated into a fight with Miao Renfeng but becomes friends with his foe. He is killed by Miao Renfeng unintentionally, as Miao's weapon had been secretly smeared with poison. * '''Miao Renfeng''' ({{zh|first=t|t=苗人鳳|s=苗人凤|p=Miáo Rénfèng|j=Miu4 Jan4-fung6|labels=no}}) is a powerful martial artist of equal fame as Hu Yidao. He is nicknamed "Golden Faced Buddha" (金面佛) and "Undefeated Champion" (打遍天下無敵手). He is slightly more conservative and does not know how to express his feelings well. He fights with Hu Yidao and is so impressed by Hu's chivalry and skill that he befriends Hu. His enemies secretly smear poison on his weapon and he kills Hu Yidao unintentionally after inflicting the latter with a minor cut. * '''Cheng Lingsu''' ({{zh|first=t|t=程靈素|s=程灵素|p=Chéng Língsù|j=Cing4 Ling4-sou3|labels=no}}) is the apprentice of the "King of Venoms". She falls in love with Hu Fei when she first meets him while he was searching for a cure for Miao Renfeng. She later follows Hu Fei on his adventures and becomes his close companion. She gives up her life to save Hu Fei, who has been poisoned. Hu Fei is deeply saddened by her loss and he buries her beside his parents' grave. * '''Yuan Ziyi''' ({{zh|c=袁紫衣|p=Yuán Zǐyī|j=Jyun4 Zi2-ji1|labels=no}}), also known as '''Yuanxing''' ({{zh|first=t|t=圓性|s=圆性|p=Yuánxìng|j=Jyun4-sing3|labels=no}}), is Feng Tiannan's illegitimate daughter. Her mother gave birth to her after being raped by Feng Tiannan and was forced to commit suicide by Tang Pei. She vows to avenge her mother and kill her beastly father (she needs to fulfil a promise to save his life thrice before she can kill him). Having taken an oath to be a Buddhist nun in her childhood, she cannot be together with Hu Fei even though she loves him.
===Antagonists=== * '''[[Fuk'anggan]]''' ({{zh|c=福康安|p=Fúkāng'ān|j=Fuk1-hong1-on1|labels=no}}) is a Manchu general and aristocrat who appears to be generous and gentlemanly, but is in fact a scheming, selfish and ruthless person. He organises a "Meeting of the Leaders" as part of a plan to keep the ''[[Jianghu|wulin]]'' (martial artists' community) under the government's control. He has a secret affair with Ma Chunhua and has a pair of twin boys with her. He tries to murder Ma later. * '''Tian Guinong''' ({{zh|first=t|t=田歸農|s=田归农|p=Tián Guīnóng|j=Tin4 Gwai1-nung4|labels=no}}) is a descendant of one of the four bodyguards of Li Zicheng. An immoral, unscrupulous and flirtatious villain, he seduces Nan Lan and causes her to abandon her husband and marry him instead. Seeking wealth and fame, he pledges allegiance to Fuk'anggan, who promises to help him become chief of the ''wulin'' in return for his loyalty and service. His dream is shattered when Hu Fei and his friends show up to disrupt the "Meeting of the Leaders" and cause a twist of events. * '''Feng Tiannan''' ({{zh|first=t|t=鳳天南|s=凤天南|p=Fèng Tiānnán|j=Fung6 Tin1-naam4|labels=no}}) is a ruthless and cruel villain, who uses his wealth and authority to bully people. Hu Fei seeks to kill him to deliver justice for Zhong A'si and his family, who were murdered by Feng. He is rescued by his illegitimate daughter Yuan Ziyi, who has made a promise to save his life thrice before killing him to avenge her mother. He dies in the chaotic fight during the election for the leader of the ''wulin''. * '''Shi Wanchen''' ({{zh|first=t|t=石萬嗔|s=石万嗔|p=Shí Wànchēn|j=Sek6 Maan6-can1|labels=no}}) is the evil junior of the "King of Venoms". He causes the death of Cheng Lingsu, but is blinded by her and meets his end at the hands of Zeng Tie'ou.
===Others=== * '''Nan Lan''' ({{zh|first=t|t=南蘭|s=南兰|p=Nán Lán|j=Naam4 Laan4|labels=no}}) is Miao Renfeng's wife. She feels unhappy after marrying Miao Renfeng, who leads a simple and frugal life as opposed to her luxurious lifestyle before her marriage. She is seduced by Tian Guinong and abandons her husband to marry Tian instead. * '''Ping A'si''' ({{zh|c=平阿四|p=Píng Ā'sì|j=Ping4 Aa2-sei3|labels=no}}) is a young man indebted to Hu Yidao, who saved his life once. He risks his life to save the infant Hu Fei and raises Hu after the latter's parents died. A humble, unassuming and shy man, he often feels inferior to others. * The '''"King of Venoms"''' ({{zh|first=t|t=毒手藥王|s=毒手药王|p=Dúshǒu Yàowáng|j=Duk6-sau2 Joek6-wong4|labels=no}}) was a herbal medicine guru who imparted his knowledge to Cheng Lingsu, the only of his students who did not betray him. * '''Ma Chunhua''' ({{zh|first=t|t=馬春花|s=马春花|p=Mǎ Chūnhuā|j=Maa5 Ceon1-faa1|labels=no}}) is an old friend of Hu Fei. She helped him years ago during the incident at the Shang Family Castle. She has an illegitimate affair with Fuk'anggan and secretly bore him a pair of twin boys. Fuk'anggan sent his men, disguised as bandits, to kill her husband and seize the boys from her. Hu Fei helps her and the twins escape from Fuk'anggan's clutches. * '''Zhao Banshan''' ({{zh|first=t|t=趙半山|s=赵半山|p=Zhào Bànshān|j=Ziu6 Bun3-saan1|labels=no}}) is a character from ''[[The Book and the Sword]]''. He is the third leader of the Red Flower Society. He meets the young Hu Fei at the Shang Family Castle and they become sworn brothers after escaping death together. * '''Tang Pei''' ({{zh|first=t|t=湯沛|s=汤沛|p=Tāng Pèi|j=Tong1 Pui3|labels=no}}) is a guest at the "Meeting of the Leaders". Initially a popular man, he is blackmailed by Yuan Ziyi and becomes despised by everyone after his dirty secrets are revealed. He is killed by Yuan. * '''Murong Jingyue''' ({{zh|c=慕容景岳|p=Mùróng Jǐngyuè|j=Mou6-jung4 Ging2-ngok6|labels=no}}) and '''Xue Que''' ({{zh|first=t|t=薛鵲|s=薛鹊|p=Xuē Què|j=Sit3 Coek3|labels=no}}) are students of the "King of Venoms" and Cheng Lingsu's seniors. They betrayed their teacher and acknowledged Shi Wanchen as their new master. * '''Shang Jianming''' ({{zh|first=t|t=商劍鳴|s=商剑鸣|p=Shāng Jiànmíng|j=Soeng1 Gim3-ming4|labels=no}}) was the master of the Shang Family Castle who was killed by Hu Yidao several years ago. Hu Fei stumbles upon the castle and runs into trouble with Shang's widow and followers when they discover that he is Hu Yidao's son. * '''Zhong A'si''' ({{zh|first=t|t=鐘阿四|s=钟阿四|p=Zhōng Ā'sì|j=Zung1 Aa2-sei3|labels=no}}) is a peasant who owns a vegetable farm. Feng Tiannan has been eyeing his farm and intends to seize that plot of land for himself. Feng accuses Zhong's son of stealing and eating a goose from his house. Zhong's wife kills the boy and cuts open his belly in a desperate measure to prove that their son is innocent. Zhong and his wife are murdered by Feng Tiannan later.

[[1080i]] ([[HDTV]]) | status = | first_run = | first_aired = {{start date|df=y|2013|7|15}} | last_aired = {{end date|df=y|2013|9|8}} | preceded_by = ''[[Triumph in the Skies]]'' (2003) | followed_by = | related = ''[[Triumph in the Skies (film)]]'' (2015) | website = http://programme.tvb.com/drama/triumphintheskies2 }} {{Chinese|t={{linktext|衝|上|雲|霄|II}}|s={{linktext|冲|上|云|霄|II}}|l="soar into the skies"|p=Chong Shàng Yúnxiao|j=Cung Soeng5 wan4-siu1|y=Chung1 Seung5 Wan4-siu1}} '''''Triumph in the Skies II''''' ({{zh|c=衝上雲霄II|s=|t=}}) is television drama produced by [[TVB]] under executive producer Tommy Leung. It is a sequel to TVB's 2003 blockbuster television drama ''[[Triumph in the Skies]]''. It stars [[Francis Ng]] , [[Julian Cheung]] , [[Myolie Wu]] , [[Fala Chen]] , [[Ron Ng]] , [[Kenneth Ma]] , [[Nancy Wu]] , [[Elena Kong]] & [[Him Law]]. The film adaption ''[[Triumph in the Skies (film)|Triumph in the Skies]]'' started production on August 6, 2014.{{cite web |url= http://www.filmbiz.asia/news/triumph-in-the-skies-feature-starts-production|title= Triumph in the Skies feature starts production|date= 2014-08-06|accessdate= 2014-08-05|work= [[Film Business Asia]]}} ==Plot== Samuel Tong ([[Francis Ng]]) resided in the UK to spend a long vacation following his wife's death. After encountering Holiday Ho ([[Fala Chen]]), a wanderer whose boyfriend died in an aviation accident, he ends his vacation early after finally making the cake that he made for his deceased wife, Zoe, he returns to Hong Kong, and joins [[Solar Airways and Skylette Airlines|Skylette Airlines]] as a pilot to fly again. He meets Captain Jayden "Captain Cool" Koo ([[Julian Cheung]]), and the two exhibit two distinct personalities, with Sam being reserved and Jayden being a man who likes to attract attention. Respectively, the two get emotionally entangled with Holiday, who arrives in Hong Kong to apply for pilot training (PPP — Pre-pilot Project). Moreover, Sam becomes a training captain to assess Jayden, leading to a competition between the two for both career and love. Jayden's younger sister Summer Koo ([[Myolie Wu]]) is an aircraft maintenance technician, and she bears grudges against her brother due to an unhappy experience during her childhood. Samuel's younger brother Issac ([[Ron Ng]]), due to Summer physically resembling his sister-in-law Zoe, is unable to turn a blind eye on it and helps settle the dispute between Summer and her brother. Summer has a crush on Issac, yet Issac restrains himself from taking another step forward in order to avoid evoking Sam's grief. In the end, the misunderstanding causes Summer to think that she was only treated like Zoe (Sam's deceased wife) in Issac's eyes. First Officer Roy Ko ([[Kenneth Ma]]) has two girlfriends and cannot make up his mind as he does not bear to hurt anyone. After sharing his secret with Heather Fong ([[Elena Kong]]), a [[Purser#Aircraft|senior purser]], Roy and she become close associates, and the two even have a one-night stand. Jim Jim ([[Him Law]]), who used to represent Hong Kong in swimming, plans to retire and enrol in flight training, where he falls in love with CoCo Ling ([[Nancy Wu]]), who is to be a [[Surrogacy|surrogate]] mother for her friend. With the planes taking-off and landing, stories of sorrow, parting, joyfulness and re-encounters have been constituted. ==Production== ===Development=== In May 2011 Tommy Leung, deputy chief director of [[TVB]]'s drama department, announced their plans to develop a sequel to ''[[Triumph in the Skies]]'' with intentions to begin filming in September of that year.{{cite news | work=IHKTV | title=TVB to film Triumph in the Skies sequel with original cast, Raymond Lam rumoured to join | date=2011-05-11 | url=http://www.ihktv.com/tvb-new-drama-triumph-in-the-skies-2.html | accessdate=2011-12-29 | language=Chinese}} Leung added that a theatrical film sequel would be made in the beginning of 2012, in hopes of boosting TVB artistes to become film stars. In June 2011, it was reported at a TVB press conference that [[Michael Miu]], [[Raymond Lam]], [[Fala Chen]], and [[Kate Tsui]] were in negotiations to join, with original cast members [[Ron Ng]], [[Myolie Wu]], [[Bosco Wong]], [[Kenneth Ma]], and [[Nancy Wu]] slated to return.{{cite news | work=IHKTV | title=TVB Power Press Conference | date=2011-06-07 | url=http://www.ihktv.com/tvb-power-sky100-press.html | accessdate=2011-12-29 | language=Chinese}} [[Jessica Hsuan]], at the time, submitted her name to be part of this series to work with Francis Ng and Chilam Cheung; but it did not work out as her contract with TVB had ended. In July 2011, Ron Ng, Myolie Wu, Kenneth Ma, Nancy Wu, Fala Chen, and Kate Tsui were confirmed to film the sequel. Following the announcement, TVB pushed back the filming schedule from September 2011 to December 2011 due to negotiation problems with ''Triumph II'''s previous airline sponsor [[Cathay Pacific]], which caused some of the newly signed cast members to withdraw, including Michael Miu.{{cite news | work=IHKTV | title=Triumph II suddenly postpones production | date=2011-07-02 | url=http://www.ihktv.com/mingpaoweekly-2225-triumphintheskies.html | accessdate=2011-12-29 | language=Chinese}} To accommodate the schedules of Ron Ng and Kenneth Ma, whom were booked to film television drama ''[[Silver Spoon, Sterling Shackles]]'' from November 2011 to March 2012, TVB postponed ''Triumph II'''s filming to May 2012.{{cite news | work=IHKTV | title=40-episode long drama 'The Prominent Family' | date=2011-08-27 | url=http://www.ihktv.com/mingpaoweekly-2233-ladies.html | accessdate=2011-12-29 | language=Chinese}} In September 2011, it was reported that [[Hong Kong Airlines]] replaced Cathay Pacific as the drama's main sponsorship.{{cite news | work=IHKTV | title=Cathay Pacific not sponsoring Triumph II | url=http://www.ihktv.com/next-1125-triumphintheskies-ii.html | accessdate=2011-12-29 | language=Chinese}} In December 2011, TVB aired a sales promotional trailer for ''Triumph II'' to attract more sponsors, which included a surprise appearance by original cast member [[Francis Ng]] at the end of the trailer. [[Julian Cheung]], who replaced Michael Miu's role in the trailer, was reportedly hired by TVB for 80,000 HKD per episode,{{cite news | work=IHKTV | title=Julian Cheung to film Triumph II | url=http://www.ihktv.com/chilam-triumph-in-the-skies-2.html | date=2011-10-08 | accessdate=2011-12-29 | language=Chinese}}{{cite news | work=IHKTV | title=Julian Cheung willing to be TVB's godson | url=http://www.ihktv.com/chilam-orbis-ambassador-child.html | date=2011-10-13 | accessdate=2011-12-29 | language=Chinese}} and later confirmed his involvement in April 2012.{{cite news | work=TVB Entertainment News via IHKTV | title=2012-04-03 Video Clip | url=http://www.weibo.com/1686300145/ycVCm1Opb | date=2012-04-03 | accessdate=2012-04-03 | language=Chinese}} Raymond Lam and Bosco Wong also appeared in the footage, but both backed out due to conflicting schedules.{{cite news | work=Jayne Stars | title=Raymond Lam and Bosco Wong will not act in Triumph in the Skies 2 | url=http://www.jaynestars.com/news/raymond-lam-and-bosco-wong-will-not-act-in-triumph-in-the-skies-2/ | date=2012-03-10 | accessdate=2012-05-26}} [[Rebecca Zhu]] was later confirmed to join the cast.{{cite news | work=IHKTV | title=Chilam rejected offer to avoid Francs Ng | url=http://www.ihktv.com/face-240-triumphintheskies-2.html | date=2011-12-28 | accessdate=2011-12-29 | language=Chinese}} On 21 December 2011, it was reported that Francis Ng was in negotiations to return.{{cite news | work=IHKTV | title=Francis Ng will return to film Triumph II | url=http://www.ihktv.com/francis-ng-back-to-the-nest-film-triumph-in-the-skies-2-laughing-brother-was-killed-by-explosion.html | date=2011-12-21 | accessdate=2011-12-29 | language=Chinese}} To accommodate Ng's schedule, filming was postponed again to September 2012,{{cite news | work=IHKTV | title=Triumph in the Skies II filming postponed to September | url=http://www.ihktv.com/triumph-in-the-skies-2-extended-shooting-francis-ng-playing-xie-tvb.html | date=2012-04-05 | accessdate=2012-04-05 | language=Chinese}} and then moved forward to July 2012. In May 2012, Kate Tsui revealed in an interview done in Australia that she had been pulled out of the cast to film a mainland Chinese drama instead.{{cite news | work=IHKTV | url=http://www.weibo.com/1686300145/ynEg67WLa | title=IHKTV's Official Weibo | date=2012-06-13 | accessdate=2012-06-13 | language=Chinese}} Following her announcement, [[Elena Kong]] and Kelly Fu were cast. On 23 May 2012, ''Next Magazine'' reported that [[Sammul Chan]] was in negotiations to return for a HK$25,000 per episode deal.{{cite news | work=Next Magazine via IHKTV | title=Shell King invites Sammul Chan to return for Triumph in the Skies II | url=http://www.ihktv.com/next-1159-sammulchan.html | accessdate=2012-05-24 | date=2012-05-23 | language=Chinese}} Chan expressed an interest, but ultimately had to reject the offer due to a schedule clash. A press conference was held on 18 July 2012.{{cite news | work=IHKTV | title=Triumph in the Skies II press conference | url=http://www.ihktv.com/triumph-in-the-skies-ii-reporter.html | date=2012-07-18 | accessdate=2012-07-18 | language=Chinese}} Season 2 premiered on July 15, 2013. ==Cast== {| class="wikitable" !align="Center" width="70px"| Actor / Actress !align="Center" width="120px"| Role !align="Center" width="350px"| Details |- | [[Pal Sinn]] ||
